Yeah, adhd and words

One of the issues that people don't understand is that language changes. So no one used the term OCD until it was created by psychologist AND then over time it entered the lexicon of "regular" people. Once it entered the common tongue the true meaning of the word/term began to diminish. This is why psychotherapist will revise the words and terms they use so that when regular people hear them they don't have a preconceived notion of what it means.

In short the people who get upset because someone says they have OCD (when they are just organized) are in the same group of people who get upset when someone says they decimated something. The "correct" usage of the word maybe to reduce by 10, but that's not what it means now or to the majority of people.

I am the girl that washes her hands until they bleed!  Well, I used to be; I've improved a lot since then, so it doesn't happen much anymore, but I still have OCD and a phobia of germs, but I've gotten better at dealing with them.  While those two things are very much linked, my other much more odd notable phobia probably isn't, although the underlying neuro stuff involved in the other two probably plays a role in the third.  What is this phobia, you ask?  Balls.  Specifically moving balls.  Different balls bother me to different degrees, with basketballs being the most, and I will absolutely get as far away from them as possible if I encounter them flying through the air, and probably cover my head and duck unless I'm trying really hard to save face.  Why am I scared of them?  Three very physically painful incidents involving basketballs, the worst one being accidentally hit in the stomach by one when the guys in my gym class were trying to show off how hard they could throw basketballs, and discovering I had appendicitis as a result.  Second worst involved the boys showing off their basketball throwing strength once again, accidentally hitting me and slamming my head into a solid metal window frame with it.  Third was when a basketball hit somehow cracked my sternum.  So now they scare me.

I have severe trypophobia. Sometimes even thinking about holes on my skin makes my heart race and i feel like i'm going to faint. I don't tell people anymore because they either a) find it hilarious or b) try to trigger it.

One time I lost a pencil (don't ask why this was the probable trigger) and I had a panic attack, a teacher came up to me asking if I was ok, and the last thing I remembered from that moment was looking at her with tear filled eyes repeating "I feel like I can't breathe" quietly. My memory cuts to sitting in the office hunched over hyperventilating while a couple people started at me, making me hyperventilate more from the attention. I was called into the nurse's office and she called my mom, put her on the phone, and I have absolutely no idea what she said. I completely forgot, but I remember the emotions I felt in those moments. Fear, sadness, anger, and betrayal. My mother decided to undermine all my feelings, I wasn't picked up that day, I had to go to class shaken up and crying because my mom didn't do a single thing to try to help. Now she still doesn't know I probably have anxiety because she doesn't pay attention. I had a second panic attack that year during school. School presentation, broke down, couldn't do it. Happened multiple times this year as well. I should really take my meds. I keep forgetting. I really do have a horrific memory, sometimes I'll forget I was even talking right after I finish saying something to someone. Article: Coping with your New Self Quarantine, Social Distancing, and Stay at Home State Directive-Order

Due to the Fact that the Corona Virus Pandemic Outbreak, many families are staying in for very long periods of time. These families, and individuals are finding themselves having to readjust their Lifestyles, normal routines, schedules, itineraries, and are juggling many other responsibilities.

While many States in America, and in countries abroad have implemented Stay at Home Directive-Orders, and Socal Distancing measures, while others are medically, or voluntarily self quarantining themselves as precautionary measures to reduce the spread of the Corona Virus.(Covid 19 virus)
Many people are now out of work, unemployed, and employment opportunities that were available 2 weeks ago are no longer exists or available due to many businesses being closed and only essential businesses are open during Stay at Home Directive-Order.

While others are working from home, and schools are closed, thus many people, and families are facing many new challenges as these families are staying in at home every day.

For most families both parents and children are all staying in for a unexpected unscheduled, unplanned vacation at Home.

Moreover, what makes this an especially difficult time, and very unfortunate, unusual set of circumstances is that many of the former forms of recreation simply are not available, due to the fact that the option of various places to patron are no longer available currently.

Additionally, while many nonessential businesses are closed, and social Distancing, Stay at Home Directive-Order, Self Quarantining measures are taking place many individuals and families may feel stressed, and overwhelmed.

I would like to Encourage these individuals and families that may be experiencing these issues to remain Focused.
Be Careful NOT TO ALLOW these difficult, and Challenging circunstances to derail, deter, or undermine your relationships with your family, friends, loved ones.
Please Be patient, kind
respectful, considerate.
It is especially important to retain your motivation despite all the ongoing difficulties taking place.

Please remain Focused, please know that this is a unexpected yet temporary set of circumstances, and we can All make it through this....

Here are some simple and practical suggestions that may help.

Try watching family favorite movies together.

Try working together as a team.
Try cleaning, and organizing, and completing other household chores together.
Try playing various games together, like checkers, cards, chess, and other board games, you may want to consider creating art, or drawing together..

Appreciate everyone's individual talents, and abilities.
Be flexible with one another, due to prior, and previous work schedules, routines, you will have to readjust, amend, and rearrange many of your activities.
This takes time getting use too new schedule,. Not working, or working at home.
Children may not be used to both parents being home every single day, all day.

Beware of any potential brewing sqaubbles, or arguments

Stay calm, and try to remain calm... take a few deep breaths and try to refocus on the importance of working on these issues together.

In addition, try not to go stir crazy while staying indoors, take time to sit outside on your fromt porch or backyard, sit on the deck, if you have one, allow for everyone to have some personal time.
Please kids be patient with Dad
Please kids be patient with Mom
Dad be patient with your spouse
Mom be patient with your spouse
Parents be patient with your children.

Friends be patient with your Friends.

Families be patient with your Family
Roommates be patient with your roommates

Everyone be patient with everyone

We must NOT give Up, the is NOT a Option.

Please be patient, and practice patience with each other, your family, friends loved ones, roommates, and everyone.

I know that it's not easy and may be a bit overwhelming, Remember that this is not forever, and while you are Coping with your New Self Quarantine, Social Distancing, and Stay at Home State Directive-Order

Remember there are some people who have no one else to help and absolutely no where to go, nothing at all.

You are all in my Prayers
We will get through this together...
Don't Give Up.. Not a Option...
We Will NOT ALLOW
COVIN 19 virus to stay or win.
I am personally experiencing some very unfair and difficult circumstances currently, therefore I fully understand, and I Encourage Everyone to stay focused, positive, and PLEASE DON'T GIVE UP!!!

Written by Advocate of Humanity, Author, Jason Sandifer,
Michigan, written on 3/25/2020, posted on
3/27/2020, 3/28/2020

I am not fastidious, and am not a germaphobe. Still, I AM overly obsessed with my silverware having to be spotless. As well, I have many repetitive behaviors and rituals, like, every night before ten o'clock I would have to shut my bedroom door, turn off the lights, lay in bed, get back up, stand on my dresser, kiss a picture twice, lay back down, sit back up, turn on my reading light, check underneath my bed, turn off my reading light, lay back down, sit back up, check my phone, lay back down. I also have to say "excuse me" three times each time I swallow (save for when I'm eating), burp, hiccup, when my stomach growls, when I sneeze, or make any other odd sound. Sometimes I have intrusive thoughts where I just HAVE to say something. I also have a list of good numbers and bad numbers that range all the way to 1,000, and if I say one I might have to list all the others up to 100 as well. When I say something under my breath to respond to an intrusive thought I have to repeat it a good number of times in different formats, and I would break down these formats into different classifications, and say each of those classifications a good number of times, as well as making sure the overall number of times I spoke was a good number, and that I had a good number of classifications. It is definitely NOT debilitating, but it is SUPER annoying and I hate it. Is it OCD?

Hi, I am not sure if I fit in the OCD spectrum, so here are some things about me and maybe someone could tell me what they think. Thank you.


I bite my hand every time I get anxious which can be up to 4 times a day. The bite almost always leaves a mark and sometimes it even bleeds a little, nevertheless often I go weeks without feelings anxious so i'm not sure if my situation could fit in the spectrum of OCD, or if it might be slight anxiety that I shouldn't worry about much. I shake when i'm anxious and laugh for no reason. Hard. I never feel like washing my hands, bathing or even like a germaphobe. Small mistakes in things do bother me, maybe more than in should because its often about just one technicality. That can really annoy me and get me anxious, but big mistakes or errors never bother me much, or at least in a unhealthy manner. I get really stressed when I am not really informed on topics, even some that I would never need to know. When I smoke E cigarettes and get a strong hit of nicotine, I cant control my thoughts, I feel very confused and feel that everything i do and say is dumb, I feel pointless and hate myself. after a few seconds of that then I just feel trapped in my own body and start shaking. After a few minutes I eventually forget everything I thought of before and just carry on with my life. I often feel insecure, different and sometimes I isolate myself and I drink a lot. I normally take about 30-40 minutes to fall asleep but sometimes I sleep very fast, depends on my mood. Its important to keep in my that I am a 15 year old boy so it might just be the hormones. I have many friends whom I love and have no problem talking to girls. Right now I am in a relationship so I experience very little anxiety, but I'm sure it will come back when the relationship ends. Music like Metal and rock often calm me. Tell me what you think if you can, Thank you.

I think ,perhaps,  the person saying it didn't address intrusive thoughts and  images meant details being covered. Not just  a thought attached to a compulsion.  Rather  on going violent or distressing thoughts that play like a movie,separate from compulsions. Seeing the violent painful death of someone you love, over  and over. Day after day. Worrying you will run circular saw over your hand  or swerve and hit a pedestrian. Even though you are being careful and do not want to. Worrying you will.  Having such horrible and real images play out in your head without your consent.  My daughter has this with her OCD.   Others we know do not. I know another who is pure O. No compulsion s at all, only obsessions.  The intense imagery seems like a  very frightening and lonely issue to bear. Definitely not the same as liking well organized cabinets.

These are things I do:
I have thoughts that go beyond my control

When I leave home I have to say "Good bye", get a response, then say "see you soon/later", then after closing the door I have to say to myself "I promise"
If I don't it feels like the whole home will burn up, or that my cat will get stuck and stranglr herself somehow.
I even say "good bye, see you soon" and then "I promise" to my cat when she is the only one at home.

I probably do lots things more THAT i don't even realize but that does affect my daily life and can tigger anxiety.

I'm glad to see this as a person with anxiety disorder and avoidance behaviors spouted my sensory issues. My classmates would always make fun of me for my phonophobia. This was particularly bad in eighth grade when we had to do an art progect on what we were afraid of, and I got teased for mine because phonophobia and photophobia aren't really rational fears like snakes or spiders. And because I need to limit external stimuli by wearing ear protection or similar guards, my classmates would always tease me. They never really understood why these guards were necessary for me. it's really sad to see the stigma surrounding mental illness so I'm glad to see someone putting the facts about it out there.

I have OCD but because it's not the one where you clean all the time or keep washing your hands, people rarely believe me. I have the kind that makes you check everything CONSTANTLY. I've driven home several time just to make sure my dog didn't escape out of the house as I was leaving even though I know I heard her barking at me from inside as I walked to my car. I'll bet you $100 that I reread this comment to check for errors several times. I'll throw in an extra $50 if I made my husband proofread it for me just so I can go ahead and post it. These examples are just the tip of the iceberg. It is absolute torture but rarely do I bump into someone who understands because they don't realize there's different types of OCD. I've gotten into a very heated argument with a girl who has self-diagnosed OCD because she likes to be organized and thinks it fun to joke about. I'm going to share this on all my different social media accounts and hopefully people will start to understand.

I’ve been told by a few therapists that I have OCD and Anxiety Disorder that can cause panic attacks. People really don’t believe me when they ask what’s wrong if I’m shaky or whispering that I answer back I have anxiety or OCD. Responding with stuff like “but you’re not that organized” or “you’re fine I have anxiety too”, but obviously it’s not the same. Like today I had a panic attack in my English class and now I’m getting my schedule changed because my teacher didn’t excuse my 504 plan so now I don’t trust her.
My fear of people and going outside was most likely caused by my birth parents that would lock me in a room or closet, sometimes days at a time.
In 7th and 8th grade I developed a phobia of school, because my school wouldn’t let me excuse myself in a panic attack or flash back from my PTSD and I’d end up in a hospital or a baker act when all I needed to do was at least step into the hall way to not be stared at like a freak show.
Most of my OCD compulsions are checking the fridge (even if it isn’t my house which seems rude. The longest I’ve done is probably just 13mins of me slowly opening and closing the door), tapping my foot in a star or square pattern when sitting, and repeating the last word I’ve said out loud in increments of 4 (most of the time I have to whisper this). If I couldn’t or can’t act these out my mind can’t focus, and some past cases lead to self harm.

I don’t really know what this would count as but if I’m not ready or expecting to be touched I have to wash what ever part of me was touched and the other side. If i can’t wash I rub it, often close to breaking the skin. I was told this was part of the OCD but 1 out of 4 doctors said she didn’t think so, so it makes me worry it’s something else though I’m pretty sure it is.

meantime anyway. This is of course
because it is likely the surest, most efficacious,
and perhaps quickest sure-fire 'cure'. But whilst sprinting out of a bus-station
screaming your way in-and-out of heart failure - you'll probably think of 'cause' and only be interested in throwing out the god-damn window.There are of course many other ways of dealing and treating anxiety, but
most people will probably do the two
most frequent, medication along with
relationship therapy.
Benzodiazepines are popular, they're
a great anaxiolytic (anxiety-killer), but they're problematic unless they are
used infrequently. This is a problem
in any event with anxiety-disorders because the
problem is too pervasive making the
probable result; tolerance, abuse, and
eventually addiction. It's been some time, but I learned of a medication counsled about from three different users. It was, for them, nothing short of miraculous. The precise 'genre' I cannot say, but it is calle Escitalopram.
It's works much-more quickly than your anxiety would preclude - believe me. I have to stop typing now. U-Tube's pissed.

As someone who has been DIAGNOSED with OCD, i really appreciate this video. I stress the diagnosed because as stated in the video, lots of ppl think they have OCD but they really don’t. I was diagnosed with it when I was 12. I take medication and see a psychologist.
Now that that’s out of the way, I want to thank you for making this video. It can be really frustrating when OCD is one of the most talked about specific anxiety disorder, but nobody really knows anything about it. Everyone’s like “omg your drawer is so messy, it’s giving me OCD” or “hey you lie things to be symmetrical? You’re so OCD” or “ugh that painting is lopsided, it’s triggering my OCD”
Nobody knows what OCD is or its symptoms or anything about it. They just think that if you’re organized or if you don’t like germs, you have it.
When I was diagnosed, I was washing my hands so much they bled. I couldn’t bend my fingers because they cracks in my hands would reopen and start to bleed again. They stung constantly. They were red and raw and cracked and bloody. You know when you’re swimming and your hands get all wrinkly? I’d wash my hands for so long that that would happen. Over and over again. I would wash, dry, and repeat forever, and eventually I was just scraping away the skin in my hands.
Then, the other compulsions. One huge and very common obsession many ppl who suffer from OCD experience is the fear of hurting yourself or someone else. I’d be shaking in the corner of my room with my door locked, sobbing, trying to tie my hands together so I would hurt anyone. I was terrified that one day for some reason, I’d just hurt sb. It was so stupid looking back on it because I know I would never hurt anyone, but these images would just pop in your head of you doing these things. I remember begging my parents to send me away and to lock me in some mental institution to get me away from them because I was so scared something would happen. I would plead with them to call the police and get them to arrest me and put me into solitary confinement. I wouldn’t hug anyone anymore because I kept seeing myself choking them. It was horrible. Going to bed took forever because of the compulsions I did. OCD is not fun.

Okay so, this is a bit of background on my life since everyone's telling their stories. (This may be triggering for OCD people, please dont read if you do get effected easily) I haven't gone to a doctor about this because I dont think it effects my life as much as it does to others. It is very slight and I can kind of control it. I think i may have some form of OCD, but not too bad. I know that sounds like I'm trying to fake an illness but I swear I'm not, I'll just tell you about some things that happen to me daily. (My brother has adhd and autism btw, you'll need this information for later) Sometimes my brother would get very upset or get hyper, and my mother tells me I often went to wash my hands because I said I felt in control, along with the fact that I distinctly remember pacing back and forth at least 7 times unlocking, relocking, twisting the knobs on the doors in the house to check if they were okay. It got so bad that at one point I was almost at ten until my mom grabbed my hand and told me I needed to go to bed and that I had just spent 30 minutes checking the doors. I got so paranoid some nights I would look at the ceiling and go back and forth on the wall, then check another just the same in continuous motions until i felt satisfied  and hadn't messed up once. I still feel some sudden urges to wash my hands vigorously. Whenever I think there's been hair in my food I feel like there's hair in the back of my throat and I start to cough to "get the hair out", the coughing got so bad one time I threw up and still coughed cause I thought the hair was still in my throat. I can't wash dishes (even if they've been precleaned by me which they usely are) without gloves on. When I think or see something disgusting I feel the sudden urge to scratch my head.(it got so bad one time I reached under my hair and it was bleeding a lot, and I had a scab for a while) whenever I get paranoid about someone or something i pace and count my steps or scratch my skin until it's bleeding. I love cleaning, and whenever I go over to a friend's house (which isn't often because of the locks thing) I always end up cleaning their house. Sometimes I look at perfectly clean items and somehow my brain convinces me they're dirty when in reality they've been washed, but then I get a maggots digging into your scalp kind of feeling and start scratching.When I was very young I would avoid cracks, and count 1 2 between them. If I messed up and touched a crack or my count got off I would stop, turn around, count my paces back and start again. I hold back a lot of my urges because people would probably judge me if I scratched my head all the time, but that doesn't mean they dont exist. As well as the fact that I could add many more experiences that I have daily that make me feel compulsed to do things unordinary. I've probably rewritten this paragraph way too many times. I hope you can see my experiences and know OCD isn't much of a joke, and I wouldn't wish it on the worst.

To sleep, the fan must be on. I must not be able to feel the breeze under the covers. My sheets and blankets must be set properly and I cannot touch wrinkles on the sheets with my feet. I cannot be wearing anything but undies and a tank top. It must be a tank top because I cannot have the seams of a t-shirt’s sleeve holes touching me while I sleep. The covers must be over my ear. All lights must be off, blinking lights/charge lights from laptops/etc. must be covered. The covers must be of a medium weight, meaning I need to sleep with more than just a thin blanket, even in the summer. I check my alarms repeatedly to make sure they are on.

When I’m not trying to fall asleep, I pick, scratch, and claw at any perceived imperfections on my skin, wash my hands constantly-they cannot get sticky, or oily, or smudged-and I destroy my nails picking at hangnails and bits of scabby skin. I average 2-3 hangnail infections a month from my picking, and have gotten used to the pain, swelling, and subsequent pus-squeezing that has become normal for me in the past ten or so years.

I despise repetitive noises (such as a faulty fan making a repeated whirring noise), blinking lights in a dark room, or specks of dust on a screen. I have to wear shorts under jeans because I can’t let the metal rivets holding the pockets touch me. I make sure to go to the dentist with my hair down because I cannot have the metal part of the bib they put on me touch my neck. I despise jewelry and can barely bring myself to touch it. The idea of wearing rings and bracelets and having earrings makes me sick. The smell of metal is so unbearably noxious to my senses it makes me ill.

I constantly have uncontrollable thoughts or daydreams punctuated by my brain going over future scenarios over and over again until I’m crying in bed from not being able to stop seeing what my brain thinks it needs to see.

This is what being “so OCD” is like. I wash my hands until, when winter comes, they crack and bleed. I cry myself to sleep sometimes when my OCD and insomnia pair up and I get no sleep. I feel like a freak when someone drops an earring and I pick it up like it’s some dead thing.

This is my life with OCD. And I can’t believe you neurotypical weirdos and your wearing jeans with nothing underneath! Are you all mad?!?

I have Entomophobia (the fear of bugs) and it’s taken over my life. I know it sounds like no big deal but honestly it sucks. I can’t sleep at night because I always feel like bugs are crawling all over me, I can actually feel movement, but nothing’s ever there. I wrap a breathable face covering (it’s meant to get rid of the dust in the air that you breathe in) around my head every night to make sure no bugs can get in my ears, nose or mouth. When I bug touches my skin I will wash the area multiple times and then for the next hour or two I won’t be able to stop itching that area. Sometimes just seeing a bug will cause me to itch my entire body. I have a huge fear of infestations which is a separate section of Entomophobia and so if I see a bug in my house I automatically assume that my house is infested and I clean for hours. I never open my windows because I’m so scared that a bug could get in. One time I was at my friend’s house and we were in her backyard and there was a tree with at least 50 moths on it and I almost passed out. I didn’t actually pass out but I had a really bad panic attack and couldn’t stop itching my arms for the rest of the day. I wish I could just be normal.

People claim that they suffer from anxiety because they get nervous when they’re at a party. Anxiety is worse than that, especially when you get an attack. You feel like you’re dying and everything that surrounds you doesn’t seem real. I usually have these attacks between 1 and 3 am. I have asked my mom and my husband to take me to the ER 3 different times the past two years because I couldn’t breathe, I begged them to take me begged for my life. I’m learning to control them and now I’m more prepared for them, learned to breathe, downloaded some games on my phone, I eat blueberries and put ice on the back of my neck, this is what works for me and sometimes I have to do all of these . It’s horrible. I’m just 20 years old and I’ve been suffering this since I was very young but I didn’t understand why my heart would beat fast in the middle of the night, always knew there was something wrong. Stay strong and please try to make lifestyle changes, wear yourself out! Don’t drink coffee after 5 pm, don’t eat too much sugar, don’t drink alcohol late at night. It sucks but that’s the life we have to live.

It sucks when you just want to be normal like the other kids. My family would often tease or worse, scold me for not being sociable like the others. I just thought I was weird at first but things got worse as I grew up. I try my best to make friends in my class, but I can't even talk normally to people without stuttering or making a weird voice then I get self-conscious and excuse myself. I would spend the day thinking how weird or bad it was to talk with people.
Then I would often ask myself what's wrong with me. It was only in college when I realized I had social anxiety disorder. Hopefully, I got better handling my anxiety. But some days, its just inevitable to feel everything so I shut myself in my room and probably be depressed about myself. I'm just thankful that there were some of my friends who are empathetic and it was nice to know that there are people on social media who experiences the same thing.

Also we have to manage our perceptions. So often irrational, devious, pervasive fear is caused by an eaually irrational, devious, pervasive belief. Which means they usually avoid you and if they don't who cares if they want to feel better about themselves

When I was in seventh grade l developed severe social anxiety and it pretty much ruined my life. I was so terrified and anxious and paranoid about having to go to school and interact with people l couldn't function. I had to be put in a special ed class because going to a bunch of different classes and seeing hundreds of other students was just too stressful to handle. I lost literally every single one of my friends because l isolated myself. Life was dull and meaningless. I didn't even feel like a real person again until l was in 10th grade and had finally develop some good coping skills and had finally integrated myself back into normal school. I have come leaps and bounds with managing my anxiety but l still struggle. I'm 19 years old now and even though my social anxiety has gone down and doesn't affect me nearly as much as it used to, l feel like it's forever damaged my ability to make and maintain friendships and I'm constantly second guessing myself.

I honestly appreciate this video so much. GAD has been a part of my life since as long as i can remember, stemming from both my predisposed genetics for it, as my mother and maternal grandmother both have GAD and major depressive disorder, and my troubling childhood that often put me in situations where I had to be the adult of my family, which led to constant worry and fear. It was only until about 7th grade when it got bad enough for me to actually physically need to see the doctor to get it addressed, which led to help, but not much. In 8th grade it got so bad that I was hospitalized for my lack of complete functioning over all. It was hard to get out of bed in the morning and I barely responded to anything and everything troubling in my life. I'm heading into to high school now, and continue to learn about my disorders, like GAD, Major Depressive, and Social Anxiety, so this video really helps, both with lessening stigma and teaching those with these disorders alike.

i know this is a late comment, but i think i have some form of an anxiety disorder, however mild. hear me out.

i have constant irrational fears and anxiety that cause me to avoid that something that is causing me those irrational thoughts. here are two good examples of this:
it was track and field, and my mom did not sign my form, because last time i participated in the event, my allergies acted up and i came home seeing blue out of my eye. me and two other students went to another class to do work. at the lunch break, i had forgotten my lunch bag in my classroom, so i went to get it. take note that i was in a portable at the time. i tried to open the door, but it was locked. you see, the intermediate and junior kids at my middle/elementary school have a different recess than the primary kids, so when we have lunch, they have recess. a few teachers were near my portable, watching the little kids. i was about to go up to the teacher to ask her to open my portable for me, but something held me back. i started to worry like crazy. what if the teacher would judge me? what if i was breaking some unspoken rule if i went and asked her? what if i couldn't disrupt her and she would refuse? so, instead of going up to her directly, i tried to wave her over, but to no avail. i eventually gave up and spent that lunch break hungry. the thing is, it's very normal to ask a teacher to open the door of a portable for you. people did it all the time, and yet i still chickened out.
another time, i woke up and was preparing waffles. i put them into the toaster and set it to 4 minutes. so, you know how sometimes, if you set the waffles for long, they come out crispy and with holes at the surface, from the heat? that's what happened to them. i KNEW it wasn't anything out of the ordinary, but i STILL was absolutely terrified. i was afraid that there was some kind of bug in my waffles and that i would be eating it if i bit into the waffle. it was very irrational, but i just couldn't shake it. i ate the side of the waffle that practically had no holes, but could not force myself to eat the other half. eventually, i just gave up and put it aside. i could not eat it.
those are only two examples, but this has happened a number of times. these two just come to mind easily.
any thoughts? i honestly don't know if it's anything serious, but i'm nervous.

I am not sure this is a panic attack: I was about to sing with my chorus at school in front of around 4 classes of kids. (6th grade btw) they weren't even in the auditorium yet! But I started to cry on stage while practicing. I asked to go to the bathroom. I ran down the hall to the office, far from the restroom, and tried to call my mom, but the office was closed after school hours so I was stuck. I was hyperventilating. I ran back and was crying and freaking out. I stood by the doors to where they couldn't see me and started to cry and hyperventilate to where I was light-headed. I went to the bathroom and tried to calm down. That is when 4 girls came in and tried to talk me out of not doing to concert in front of other kids. I was dead set on going home and avoiding the peer concert all together and just doing the parent concert. One of the girls left to get someone to calm me down. Then the other three did something soooo stupid. They were pulling me and pushing me trying to get into the auditorium and out of the bathroom. (I am not exaggerating) When I saw the other classes started to come down the hall, I started to resist even more by clinging to the bathroom wall. I hate germs but I didn't care at the time. I just didn't want them to see me like this. I clung to that wall like if I didn't I would fall in a volcano. They were grabbing my arms and trying so hard to push me into the auditorium. Then my chorus's assistant for the day came out and he tried to calm me down, outside of the girl's bathroom. I ended up going home and having no problem at all doing the parent concert. I freaked out so bad, I thought I was having a panic attack but I am not sure. Thanks for reading my crazy story. If you can confirm that, that would be awesome! ;3

A couple years back I was diagnosed with GAD, ADHD, depression, and a mood disorder. Nowadays I know how to pick out what specific triggers I have, I'm no longer depressed, and I'm pretty sure my mood disorder was just my hormonal teenage brain dealing with an awful situation poorly, so I probably need an update on my diagnosis. During the situation that led to my disorders, I worked as a library aide. Half a year ago, I walked into a bookstore only to discover that certain book covers and spines are a major trigger. So my situation somehow got associated with the books I had shelved for two years, and I had only found out WAY after the fact because I just happened to not go into book stores and libraries for a couple years. I'm really mad and embarrassed, because honestly, they're just BOOKS! I'm able to pick out what specific shades of colors I need to avoid before I start slowly exposing myself to them. This is especially devastating for me because I plan to be a librarian. A librarian who can't look at certain books, could you imagine?

To cope with this, I began talking to myself (no, I don't hear voices, the only voice I hear when talking to myself is mine and I'm fully aware I'm talking to myself) and developed trichotillomania (a body repetitive compulsive disorder). I don't know if I have anxiety, but I think I might. I tend to worry, overthink, have compulsive behaviors, I get so nervous I shake/tremble uncontrollably, and what bothers me is that I know that if I stop and take a breath and relax, I'd eventually calm down. However, I tend to make the usually conscious decision to let myself slide into this irrational fear and to feel sorry for myself. Once I let go, my thoughts turn into flashes, my extremities start tingling and go numb, and at times I can't breathe. I have dealt with chest pain from being sad and nervous, and I do tend to "beat myself up", but what I don't understand is that if I truly have anxiety, why am I still able to think rationally that if I were to calm down, I'd take control of myself again? I don't know. I'm just tired of everything.

I had my first panic attack when I was sixteen. The hours before it, I felt uneasy, and tried to eat and distract myself from this strange sensation of a ticking bomb inside my chest. Every face I encountered in public seemed suspicious and potentially dangerous, though I didn’t know why. I walked home after eating, and began to lose my breath, like if I were drowning. I went up the elevator inside my building and tried to contain whatever was happening until I got home. When I finally arrived, I began crying and hyperventilating in front of my mother for no particular reason other than to release myself from the enormous fear that was creeping over me all throughout the day. I always sensed I had some form of anxiety, and having my GAD confirmed was a huge step forward in my mental health.

However, when I got diagnosed with OCD, I was very confused. All I could picture was someone who washed their hands so much that their skin was irritated (like Michael J. Fox on Scrubs).

Once I remembered my nine-year-old self showering in under two minutes (and counting them in her head) while stepping away from the drain because if I didn’t, some malevolent force would try and hurt me, it made much more sense to me.

OCD is fed by intense and disturbing thoughts (obsessions) that are eased by various kinds of behaviors (compulsions) both physical (tapping, cleaning) or mental (counting, ritualized thought suppression), and eventually become ritualized. It is a shame it took me so long to fully understand it. I still struggle with both my disorders on a daily basis, but gaining some awareness and realizing I am not my thoughts was the most powerful of them all.

This video takes the disorders to the extreme. OCD has lesser conditions that aren't as traumatic. I know a few people who have diagnosed OCD. Not every person who has these disorders have the same levels of it or exact same situations.

My OCD is that I have to do random things throughout my day over and over until I get them "right", and if I try to ignore it, my brain would tell me that someone I love will die. Let's say, for example, that I was closing a door. If I do it "wrong" the first time, I open it and close it over and over until I get it "right". This can be as small as that, and it can get as big as a series of actions like going to the bathroom and picking up a snack and then pouring a glass of water. If I mess even the smallest thing up, I'd go back to where I started, and then start making my way to the bathroom again. The things that define "right" and "wrong" are things like how many times I've done it, what I was thinking while I was doing it, how many steps I've taken, etc. This has sometimes taken hours out of my day. It is truly a living hell.

Thankfully, I started taking medication for it, and it started to get better. If you have OCD or any other mental disorder, you are not alone and it will not last forever, I promise :)

I have been diagnosed with generalized anxiety, social anxiety, and OCD. I worry endlessly about trivial things, and I often feel like I have no control over my life. I have an irrational fear of talking on the phone with strangers even though I can talk to strangers in person without feeling any anxiety over it. I always feel like I am being judged by other people. I just feel ugly or weird around others, I guess. As for the OCD, I have intrusive thoughts about stabbing myself in the throat or eyes (I would never, ever do this; it causes me great distress), several ritualistic behaviors, and the ridiculous idea that thinking about awful things will actually cause those awful things to happen in real life (and to prevent it from coming true, I have to repeat certain phrases in my head). I also "feel" like inanimate objects have feelings, even though I am well aware of how dumb that is. They are not delusions because I know that they are stupid, but they are pretty close, I think. I also have major depressive disorder, ADD, and PTSD from finding someone I knew after he shot himself with a shotgun. My brain is messed up pretty bad. It really sucks. My only relief is distracting myself by learning. It's the only thing that brings me any pleasure or joy. Anyway... at least I don't have something even worse.

Hi Hank, I love watching your videos, they're really helpful. I've noticed on a few occasions that you've referenced how difficult it is to tease apart the overlapping symptoms of disorders. I've been thinking about the same thing, and I've realized; maybe it's due to the fact that we're trying to oversimplify this. If you look at the bigger picture of the realm of disorders, taking anxiety for example, you'll notice there can be broader terms to explain the symptoms; such as external vs internal symptoms. For example, external symptoms can range anywhere from the fear of how others will judge you at a social event to the phobia of having another panic attack on the bus in front of all those people, and internal symptoms can involve things like a reinforced behavior developed from appeasing anxiety by removing oneself from the situation. Just some food for thought. I hope you see this comment. Keep up with the awesome videos! :D

I have paranoia and don't like to be alone and I care a lot about people and how they think of me. I can't be left alone for very long periods of time, especially at night. I like to be alone because it gives me some 'me time' and it's just nice. But my front door has a glass part in it where you can kind of see outside. Each time I pass it I HAVE TO check it. It's compulsive. I check for movements and shape figures. And if I'm walking around and hear a noise, I stop, go stiff, my heart begins to race and I feel like a fricken deer or somesort of animal. I run and jump around, making the least amount of noise possible, I even run passed the door as fast as possible. I start to shake as well. You better believe I don't move when I hear that doorbell or hear the phone ring. I used to stay inside my room once I was alone and didn't come out until someone came home. I didn't even leave to use the bathroom. Sometimes I still do that. For hours.
I care a lot about how people view me. I have friends and I hate thinking about how they're slipping away from me, while they're probably not, so I'm becoming very clingy. If I don't talk to a person I care about regularly (everyday), I get really scared and paranoid. I even do this with strangers. If I walk by someone and I hear them laugh, I'll immediately think their laughing or talking about me. I try to brush it off until I forget about it, but it happens a lot.
I don't know if any others have this type of paranoia but there are some cases where it's just my mind and I know it, yet I still hate it. I feel as if there are cameras in my room, that people can read my mind, that things can pop out at me. I check the halls whenever I walk out of my room to make sure no one's there. I check above me as well. When ever I think that someone can read my mind, I think of a distraction to see if anyone is doing so, like imagining something crashes through the wall; who ever flinches or looks in the direction of the distraction is obviously reading my mind. I do this everyday as well.
When I wake up in the middle of the night, I immediately thinks there's this ungodly creature waiting for me to move. So I don't move. At all. And I know it's not real and I'm fine, but it's just my mind and it's just like, "Yeah, you're gonna die if you move. Hope you're not planning on sleeping". I get a stress headache from the fear.
Why I rant about this? This is a really long "comment" but yeah.

This is a great video but you forgot one very important thing. The freeze response. There is fight, flight, and freeze. Sometimes we freeze when we feel like we can't escape a bad situation. Like children being abused by their parents. Or a spouse being abused by spouse. Peer pressure at school. Being raped and not fighting back is the freeze response. The primal purpose of this response is to protect yourself emotionally from what is happening to you. This leads to dissociation and a tendency to freeze in vaguely similar situations. I have anxiety disorder and I did get small anxiety attacks every now and then. But around 2-3 years ago, I had my worst ever. A full blown panic attack. It held on for an entire week and I still suffer the aftermath. I'm a bit shaky, somewhat paranoid, tense and always scared of having another panic attack almost every day and being alone when that happens. So, even if I'm 21, leaving my parents side is somewhat difficult, because they are the ones that understand me and will be around me whenever I get another attack.
I refuse to sleep in my own bedroom at my parent's house, where I used to have a lot of these smaller attacks and the nagging feeling of isolation and no where to go. Now I sleep on the couch in the living room and it feels so much better, mostly because it was there I eventually calmed down.

A panic attack feels just like what you said. For me, my entire body just froze. I rarely left the couch. I was hyperventilating, I felt cold, my heart raced and I felt like I was dying and/or going absolute crazy. You're scared of hurting others. Hurting your loved ones. Hurting yourself. You're scared of your own thoughts. I was always scared to move from my spot. I was scared to talk about my thoughts, since they were nothing but dark and distressing. My poor Mom couldn't even watch her favorite crime shows, because I got an anxiety attack as I believed I was going just as crazy as the bad guys in them. It's really horrifying.

After my attack, my Dad (who usually thought I was just being a bit whiny) understood what I actually went through. I think that week really scared him. Now he's always asking me to take my medicine when I need to and he scolds me for forgetting them too. I do feel really awful for making them worry like that. My Mom is even more stern, mostly because she has anxiety as well.

To this day, I wouldn't wish an anxiety attack upon anyone I dislike. Ever.

I hate it when people say that they have OCD when they don't or say that something that they did is "so OCD" so for all of those people, here's a story. I told my friend that I had moderate to severe OCD (which I do) and she said to me "no you don't" it was infuriating, but I told her that she shouldn't make judgments like that, and that every time that the "voice" inside my head told me to do something that I would tell her (and do it, of course) and That's exactly what I did, I told her every time something had to be an even number  or every time I counted things 10 times, I even told her her the next day after I didn't listen and had a mental breakdown and cried so hard for so long that I threw up and didn't sleep the whole night because I was cleaning and organizing everything to make up for it. When people come up to me and ask "do you think that I have severe OCD?" I want to ask them have you spent 2 hours opening and closing a drawer until you break down in sobs because you feel that you have lost complete control of yourself? but I never do because I know beter. I didn't write this comment for people to feel bad about misjudging OCD I just wrote it so that you understand what it's like to have OCD

I was diagnosed with minor OCD disorder as a kid, but my symptoms aren't as severe as I many times see people say, leading a lot of people to think I'm just "faking it" or using OCD as a punch line. I have an obsession with turning off lights and shutting things like doors, windows, ice holders, anything that can be shut. I can't really say why I feel these urges to close things or turn off lights when I leave a room, but if I don't do it, it bothers me until I go back and do it. I also have an obsession with things being symmetrical or in order in some way. I feel weird if I take out a piece of gum and don't rearrange the pack to be symmetrical, or if someone messes up my system of keeping purses in boxes by size. That's why many times when someone says they have a bit of OCD because they like to stack their towels in a certain order, or clean their bathroom the exact same way at the same time every week, I believe them. Sometimes it's not something you can explain. You just have to do it, or you feel this nagging sensation at the back of your head, or shake, or can't focus.

And then there are the wonderful, strong, scared shitless of us that have several of these. I have both GAD and Social Anxiety. And they kind of mush together and feed each other. It's hard to do things that others find simple and normal, like a phone call. And you KNOW it should be normal to you too, but it isn't. And it makes you feel worse, the GAD kicks in and just tears you down so you can build yourself back up again to just repeat that next time. It's like walking up stairs without ever reaching the top. You are scared, it causes you to sweat like hell, then you know people notice your forehead drenched in sweat and you sweat more because of it and so it goes on. And then there are good days when you can stand in a line in the grocery store without the feeling of panic and shame accompanying you. And then with time and effort there are more of the good days than the bad. But then again I do avoid the things that make the days bad.

I'm starting to think I have an anxiety disorder. It would explain quite a few things...

OCD is not adjusting tables so they're satisfying. OCD is not "satisfying."
OCD is checking things more than once. It's re organizing too often. It's sensory issues. OCD is getting anxious in every situation because of certain possibilities. OCD is having to repeat yourself. OCD is absolutely HAVING to do something. I'm sick of wrong impressions of OCD. It's germs creeping up into your skin, washing your hands after you shake hands with someone. It's the same thought racing through your mind. It's thoughts never stopping racing through your mind. It's things you find uncomfortable racing through your head.
It's not a quirk. It's not something to brag about. It's not funny. Stop it.

So I am taking Abnormal Psychology right now. we just talked about fear vs. anxiety. Fear is a response to something that is ACTUALLY happening, versus anxiety which is a response to something that you are anticipating is GOING to happen.

The video didn't mention agoraphobia which is a complication of panic disorder (not a fear of public places as people often think). It's characterised by a fear of having a panic attack in a situation that might be difficult or embarrassing to escape from, so you feel trapped because you either can't or shouldn't leave the situation. I have emetophobia (fear of vomiting) which is a big factor in my panic disorder (when I have an attack I don't feel like I'm dying, I feel like I'll either be sick or pass out) which in turn has caused agoraphobia. Fun times!

I 100% believe I have a social anxiety disorder and panic disorder. At my junior high, they brought in some mental health professionals, and had some of us take tests and then talk with the staff after. The test results showed that a panic disorder and social anxiety was present, but when I tried to explain my panic attacks, the lady quickly wrote me off and said it wasn't panic attacks. Uhm, excuse me? I got so stressed out at a restaurant one time I couldn't breathe, accidentally made myself vomit and just cried in the bathroom for over ten minutes, and here you are telling me that it's not valid? Anyways, she said I probably had a social anxiety disorder but said I might say something to my parents about a follow-up with a doctor. I told my parents, and they kind of just wrote it off. I have some "coping mechanisms," bur they don't help me whilst in the social situations I get crippling fear during. I know everyone I've talked to says being diagnosed with a disorder was the worst day of their life, but my parents seem to be avoiding my diagnosis and making me deal with it. I actually got up the courage to ask about anti-anxiety meds to my mom, and she said they increase depression, especially in teens like myself. I already have mild depression, so why not prescribe me a low dose of anti-depressants? She takes both those medications (though she has GAD) so I thought she would understand. But it doesn't really seem like she does. For example, I've been wanting a ukulele for a really long time. We went to the store and I found one I liked, but the part where they kept the ukes and guitars and such was in an different room than everything else, so no workers were there. My mom said I had to go and tell a worker I wanted to buy it, but I couldn't, We wasted half an hour with me just shaking my head and her and my sister trying to convince me it was easy. To me, it just isn't. My sister definitely doesn't understand that, and my mom hasn't been affected by her anxiety for years, due to the medication. She eventually got tired of it and asked someone, but was annoyed with me later. I don't know how to bring it up again, and I'm afraid she thinks I'm making a bigger situation out of nothing, and that is so prominent I'm wondering it too.

I'm happy to say that thanks to a combination of therapy and medication, I am doing much better than I was before. I've always been on the skittish side and come fifth grade I was diagnosed with Anxiety when I had my first panic attack (or at least when I first figured out what those episodes of intense fear were called.) It was tough, but I saw various therapists and managed to somewhat gain control over my anxiety. Then suddenly, in my second year of high school, that all fell apart. My panic attacks spun out of control and very soon I was barely able to leave home because of how severe my attacks and fear of future attacks was. I was missing school and driving my poor mom nuts. She did her best to comfort me whenever I had attacks and was always there for me but then she also got understandably frustrated with me, too. Finally I went to a psychiatrist to try medication, my parents weren't too thrilled about it because they were afraid it'd turn me into a "zombie", but in fact after I started taking it things started to look up. It didn't happen all at once, after all medication takes time to build up and start working and even with the medication helping I still had to bite the bullet and go back to school and try to piece my life back together after it had very nearly fallen apart. It wasn't easy, but thanks to my meds, the support of my friends and family, and my own perseverance I was able to tough it out and get my life back. I'm proud to say I'm finishing my second year of college and panic attacks are nearly a thing of the past for me. I still suffer from mini panic attacks from time to time and, rarely, bigger ones, but I'm able to function and stand on my own two feet and I'm no longer terrified of leaving the house or of going places by myself. :)

I have ocd and secretly can't stand when people who don't have it say they have it because they're well organized or something.  I say secretly because if you actually have it, you probably don't want to broadcast it to the entire world.  It's not a good thing.  It's not something you brag about everytime you've been tasked to organize something.  It's a debilitating disease that you have to struggle with every minute of every day just to feign normalcy and (pretend to) live a normal life.  Imagine literally having to face your deepest fears and go against your anxieties and instincts ALL THE TIME just to fight and hide a crippling disorder which will ruin you utterly and completely if you let it.  That's ocd.  Being neat and organized is not ocd.  OCD is nothing to brag about

I think that a lot of people forget or just don't know what anxiety really is when I talk to other people about these kinds of disorders. Anxiety has been an... emotion... or feeling that has been associated with humans most likely for the last hundreds of thousands of years. It's basically our brains telling us that it can't process a situation. Or that the outcome of a situation was uncertain. So when hunters found themselves surrounded by predators, for example, they would experience anxiety. Why was this useful? Well think about the symptoms of anxiety. The two most common (and vague) symptoms of anxiety are Hypervigilance and Sweating. For those of you who don't know, hypervigilance is basically sensory sensitivity. Meaning you hear better, see better, can focus better, etc.... which is a dead give away of why it could be use full in a high stakes situation. And sweating, well... you need to keep your body cool. Any ways. Anxiety is a tool that we humans have been equipped with, to help us survive. The problem today is that people are finding it harder and harder to differentiate between situations that should cause them anxiety and situations that shouldn't. So these symptoms are coming at unwanted times. What I'm basically saying is that people don't know how to process complicated situations anymore thanks to our societies accomplishments of eliminating such complications. So now we're stuck with this fight or flight mode and our brain is turning it on when our socks don't match. The fix is simple. Teach our children how to keep calm and process difficult situations instead of keeping them protected from anything and everything from the outside world. Or they are going to end up thinking that not bringing a pen to class is the end of the world. And they're going to be "diagnosed" with an anxiety disorder.

please understand that there is more than one form of OCD, it bothers me so much when my friends call people "so OCD" growing up with ruminating OCD i worried about whether my decisions were right and how they would come back a bite me. example, for getting a c+ on a math test could mean me failing math that year which leads me not to get into a good college which means i will have no job or not a very good one, meaning i will have no money to buy a house and buy food which means I'll be homeless and starving and freezing in the winter, which will ultimately lead to my death and unhappiness. As you were reading this you probably considered this something that you do or is very common, yes it is, everyone does it, but what differs me from you or ruminating to normal is that this thought can be all i think about in a day, or a week, or a month, and it would be considered and obsession hence the name obsessive compulsive disorder. I worry too much, my decisions, other people's decisions they could be all i think about. So when i must explain that i have OCD, the first things anyone ever says to me is "but your not clean" and that's true, my rooms is a mess, i never do my laundry, my lockers a mess, but it's probably because i spend all my time thinking things over and over and over. The definition of obsession or obsess is "preoccupy or fill the mind continually, intrusively, and to a troubling extent." nowhere in this dictionary definition do i see the word clean, neat, tidy. OCD in general needs to have more light shed on, please educate others

Thank you for bringing up 'Fear of Panic Attacks', that's exactly what I have. It's hard to explain it to people without sounding ridiculous and insane, I take comfort that this is a recognized and common phobia. What I'm not wild about; is the cognitive 'cure' for it, which is to have an attack and not resist it. My panic attacks at their worst, can lead me to lose consciousness and suffer convulsions, which looks like an epileptic seizure. I've had three in my life, and they are the absolute worst! The last one I had, I collapsed in a First Aid course (the definition of 'irony' could have this story as a description). I was temporarily blind, deaf, dumb and numb...but somewhat aware of what was happening. I could feel myself breathe and my eyes bulging in the back of my sockets, without a doubt the most terrifying few minutes of my life! An ambulance was called and I was sent to hospital. I had to lie and say that my blood sugar was low, mostly because I had no real clue what had really happened. Ever since then, I've been constantly petrified that it'll happen again, especially in public!

I'd like to point out there is also OCPD (Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder) which is more similar to what people generally call OCD. As opposed to OCD it is not controlled by anxiety and not about compulsively needing to repeat behaviors, but rather it's an obsession with having things a certain way. OCD generally makes the sufferer, well, suffer, whereas those with OCPD tend to see no problem with their behavior. Excessive perfectionism, a crippling need to have things organized a certain way, inability to adapt to new circumstances etc. are symptoms of OCPD. I do recommend everyone to read a little about it!

I've always suffered with moderate to severe anxiety, however, it wasn't until last year when I developed severe anxiety that I realised i was bad. I couldn't stop washing my hands as I feared that my belongings would get infected/contaminated. This, of course, resulted in very bad skin issues as I washed them till they bled. My hands were very bad/disgusting which caused me to not want to touch anyone I deemed clean as I didn't want to scare them. Long story short, I have since recovered. I moved house with my family, forced to live in a room that didn't feel like my own for a month, I cried a lot, but I don't have the same obsession anymore. I am able to have only 1 shower a day without having panic attacks, I can go outside without needing to change clothes and have showers before sitting on my chair, and, in general, I am more able. My thoughts go out to anyone suffering to any mental illness, especially OCD. P.s. my compulsions have changed and are now more minor.

Since being diagnosed with bipolar disorder, I've thought a lot about how I feel when people use the term casually (and incorrectly). I've decided not to be bothered by it except when people are so adamant of someone's moody/erratic/indecisive behavior that they say "they are LITERALLY bipolar" or "no, seriously, I think they should be diagnosed with bipolar!" I'm bipoplar but actually a pretty consistent person when it comes to passing emotions- I've got a fairly benign disposition. Sometimes during a particularly awful pit or peak my behavior is abnormal but only in a way close friends and family would notice (staying in my room, weird sleeping hours, super distracted, etc.). If people want to say "omg, they're so bipolar" about someone who was happy this morning but now grumpy, or about someone who wanted a burger but now wants a salad, even though that's just average moods, then whatever. I'm not going to cry over it. But once you start seriously trying to (incorrectly) diagnose that person, I'm going to get annoyed.

I still remember when I was in high school I have to do a biology presentation in front of the class. Mind you my school was pretty new at that time so the student population are low. So there were only about 6 students plus a teacher in my biology class. My social anxiety was so apparent as I was presenting in front of them my legs and hands were shaking, I have to clench my left arm hard in order to not look like I'm having seizures. I was sweating, stuttering and my heart keeps beating tremendously. If you took IB program in high school you'll know that we have to do A LOT of presentations. It is indeed a bittersweet experience to think of it, I hate it for the fact that I have to do presentation in front of people while struggling with this social anxiety, but also I do feel grateful because I got no choice but to practice to get over my social anxiety by doing tons of presentations. Because if not I would avoid them at any cost and stuck in anxiety loop forever. I'm in college now and I can feel my anxiety are lower than my high school days, I get less sweating & shaking, I started converstations (which I've never dared to do it before) and even I volunteered to do something. I didn't say that I beat my anxiety, I still do feel it sometime nowadays. but what I want to say is that you CAN do it, you CAN get over this sooner or later. It's not an instant process, but it will be as long as you want to do it. Take this from someone who used to eat lunch at school bathroom because she was afraid eating lunch with the rest of the students or refuse taking phone calls inside a car with my parents present.

I don't know what to do about myself, because I don't know if I have OCD or it's just something I do out of habit or if I have anxiety or I'm just really nervous. I can't ask the doctors about it because I'm scared that if I tell my parents about it, they'll just think I'm lying or something.

So I cannot stand it when things aren't symmetrical. If I have two things on the left, there must be two things on the right. If I chew three times on the right side of my mouth, I have to chew three times on the left or else I'll feel out of balance. It's stressful because I can't focus on what I'm doing without thinking if it's going to end up symmetrical. If I do projects, everything has to be perfectly symmetrical or else I'll flip out, start over and waste time. Is that considered OCD?

I don't know also if I'm depressed (on a mild level) or if I'm just sad. More often than not, I space out at random times and end up feeling horrible even if nothing happened. I get a very heavy feeling in my chest at random times in the day or in the night.

I get a dreadful feeling every time I go on social media because I had an issue with cyber bullying. I can't tweet or post something without checking the content five times. If I see a tweet, sometimes I panic and think it's about me, and delete my tweets or posts or whatever.

There are times where I just don't want to go to school and end up not getting sleep because I dread the next day, what people will think of me, if people would attack me for the things I said online even though I barely checked my social media.

Can anyone help me? I don't want to self-diagnose or go to a hospital yet but I want to figure out myself.

I have a couple of questions: First, would stage fright/performance anxiety be some kind of social anxiety disoorder? I ask because I'm a musician, and whenever I get in front of people to play or sing, or even just to talk, I get extremely shaky and irrationally nervous. Even if I know the people I'm in front of, and even if I know the situation going in, I still have these feelings. It doesn't bother me if I'm part of a group, but as soon as I feel like I'm the center of focus, I freeze up and it completely messes with my mind and has a noticeable effect on my performance.
My second question is a little more complicated. For a while now, I've been wondering if I have slight generalized anxiety disorder. I often find myself worrying about almost everything imagineable, but it doesn't usually happen every day. It also affects me more at night. I guess my question is this: How do I know weather or not my worrying is normal, or actually a sign of GAD?
Any answers are welcome. :)

Being an OCD victim , i would like to add few things . One of the causes for OCD is the environment you are in that makes you perceive things that you don't like.
Specific things that does not go well with your brain ( a smell, a person, or specific topic ) makes you anxious, irritated, scared, that is somewhat normal , as a normal human your brain might avoid it , presumably with some time that thought leaves your brain.
But for OCD victims, the thought latches on to the brain like a parasite and produce plethora of additional unwanted negative thoughts which panics you more. Now this original thought coupled with unwanted thoughts are Obsessions. These are never ending like a loop.
Now in order to avoid the panic and stop this intruding thoughts, the victim would counter attack the thoughts and self assuring that he is "winning" by doing some rituals ( gestures like washing hands, shouting , doing the same thing he was doing when that thought occurred to him) and these are called compulsions.
This whole circle of obsession-compulsion continues in a loop as long as the compulsion won't give a positive thought that would negate the negative thoughts initially produced by the original thought which in turn was produced by the environment surrounding him/the way he is perceiving things .
Now why your brain behaves like this is something no one knows (some attribute to lack of serotonin). It might be hereditary as well.
This is why i presume most of OCD victims are socially disconnected. They never know what thought will cause them to behave like a maniac doing the irrational rituals recursively.

As a person who's has anxiety disorders and panic attacks - and grew up with many phobias, it bothers me the way the word 'phobia' is tacked onto all kinds of different social/political causes.
"Homophobia/ Islamophobia / Transphobia / Christianophobia" -
NO!!
It is NOT the same thing!

Not liking someone / not approving how another person lives / not agreeing with what you believe in is NOT a 'phobia'. I once ran out of my job as a cashier screaming because someone put a live fish on the belt and it started flopping about. I'm phobic about fish. I left my cash drawer open, and was running out the parking lot before I knew it. I couldn't even explain. I just freaked the hell out. I was 8 mos pregnant at the time and that episode sent me to the hospital. So NO. A person who doesn't like gay people etc isn't "phobic" - they just don't like it. Calling people 'phobic' when they're not only confuses people as to what this medical condition really is, and makes it seem 'lesser'. Like if you have a real phobia you are somehow a bad person, a hateful person. People start to associate 'phobia' with 'hateful'.
-NO!
It is NOT the same thing!

Like washing my hands (any hand contact with potentially dirty surfaces makes me want to wash my hands asap, and this feeling is lingering around up 'till I finally get to wash my hands, or at the very least apply some disinfecting liquid I carry around), re-checking (like, my house door. Sharing in case it helps someone: I used to have around 2-3 panic attacks per day for 6 months last year, and the thing I learned that helps me slowly "snap off" it its distracting me using one of the 5 senses. Ex: While I was having a panic attack my mother gave me to hold a cream because she thought the scent of it would help, but what actually helped a lot was the cold container of the cream that had been in the fridge. Brain went from "I'm dying, I'm dying, I'm dying" to "what is this cold thing on my hand", it helped to snap off.
Hope this is useful to someone.

I have a very heavy form of OCD, that I've been able to work through for many years to make it less annoying. The worst of it was when I was around 10, living with my family. Whenever they would get a cold or allergies, they would blow their nose in a Kleenex, and sometimes forget to throw it away. Every time I would walk into a room and see a dirty Kleenex, it wouldn't just annoy me, it would eat at me until I ran out of the room. Even if I was no where near it. That was just one of the things that would bug me on a daily basis. I would also, as a 7 year old child, go for days or weeks convincing myself that I was the only thing alive and everyone else was an illusion. I was the world's youngest Solipsist, although I probably didn't know that word yet.

I think I'm starting to develop a compulsion. I see people on the internet who are hurt and sad and depressed, sometimes suicidal, or sometimes I just need to check if there is anybody new under certain videos. I have....well I just sort of say that I have 'an anxiety disorder' because none of the professionals can agree on which one(s).
I just sort of wanted to share a personal experience of mine with panic attacks. They would come completely at random, totally unpredictable. I remember one in particular was really, really bad. I suddenly became completely convinced that I was going to die that night. I was crying, I couldn't breathe at all, I could barely even move I was so terrified. I just curled up in front of the heater and wrote letters to all the people I thought I was leaving behind. I was so convinced that I was going to die. I legitimately couldn't breathe, my chest was so tight I was fighting for breath.
For no reason at all. It was just a normal night and then out of nowhere I just got consumed by fear. It was kind of the worst thing I've ever experienced. So yeah, panic attacks... not fun.
For a while I was having much smaller panic attack every day. They weren't as catastrophic as that big one, but every single day at one point or another I would find myself just terrified for no reason and struggling to breathe. I had to start homeschooling myself because of it.
Again, not fun. I'm still not even sure why I am like this.


Anyway, I just wanted to share my personal experiences on the matter. Thanks for listening.

I have Pure O OCD (yes, diagnosed before anyone starts), which is a type of OCD without high recognisable and observable compulsions, making it more about the terrible intrusive thoughts. I'm a super messy and disorganised person, and I don't impulsively check my oven, but I do have terrible life ruining thoughts that have me avoiding situations out of major fear, avoiding family and friends, constantly checking my body responses and seeking reassurance from anyone from professionals to family to the internet. It sucks! And it took me so long to realise what was wrong with me because so few people know anything about Pure O. Goes to show that not everything fits a stereotype, and I wish people were knew more, so getting help would be easier.

This video became very helpful in understanding the uncomfortable feelings I had in the past months. I got diagnosed with social anxiety disorder maybe half a year ago. Since that day I'm working on it with my therapist to make my life bearable for me so I can get through my day which includes school and other public activities without me getting highly anxious or having a panic attack. It takes small steps, but I already realized it got better. I'm able to go shopping in a big city again, though I still fe nervous and a little anxious about it, but not freaking out days before it actually happens. I'm also not that afraid of panic attacks anymore because I know that my best friend, who's with me most of the time, recognizes very small symptoms and manages to remember me to breathe and calm myself down again. Seeing a therapist as a person with such a disorder is definitely something I'd recommend. Therapists can help you find techniques to talk yourself out of anxiousness, how to cope with stress and fear and how to accept it as a part of you, but not as a part that just controls you.
So please seek out and stay safe everyone. Stay strong. x

As a child, I hated sleeping over at someone else's place. Didn't matter who it was, didn't matter how their sheets smelled. I usually had fun with them until we we went to sleep. However, in trying to sleep, I'd get what I'd later identify as a panic attack: Violent, fast heart-beat, the fear of dying or never getting back, the urge to cry or puke. I remember it being embarrassing afterwards, because I couldn't identify the source of fear. I still can't. Mom told me I was homesick, and my friends made fun of me for it. I would be terrified of feeling it again, and so I just never had sleepovers. Class trips was probably the worst, as I knew there was no way for me to be alone and calm down.
Avoiding sleepovers of any kind for a few years went okay, and I gradually managed to sleep at others' houses. I thought it had stopped, though I still fear it every time I'm in the same situation. I got it once again in my own bed, the exact same feeling, as a cruel reminder, but it left me only with the realization that I was never homesick all those times in the past. Too bad no one knew. Though I suppose there was nothing to do about it.

If i should describe OCD in one sentence, id say it is being a slave to the mind. And that goes for most mental illnesses. We need to understand that we are not our mind or thoughts, we are conciousness and the mind is just meant to be a tool for us to use, but instead we are being used by it. We can stop letting the mind control us and instead make it our servant and friend, but we need to learn the truth about how life really works, otherwise we`ll keep being trapped. Google Truth Contest and read The Present, its the most complete explenation of life and how it works, and it applies to everyone, and people who suffer can often relate even more to it than "normal" people.

I know that, to this day, I can't make a phone call to someone, despite being a teenager with a small group of friends. I use to not even be able to answer a phone call, pretending to become sick or to be gone to avoid people that I considered very close friends. They were not amused. Also, just this year, my English teacher made us do speeches to practice public-speaking. The first speech was a disaster. I was so upset and anxious that I couldn't sleep for nearly the whole week before the speech. I even begged the councilor to give me a pass from speaking for one day. Then, the next day, I was sitting there for ten minutes before we started speaking writing 'I hate speeches.' over and over again in my English notebook. I was having a very hard time breathing and crying my eyes out. When it was my turn to read my speech I still couldn't stop myself from crying and couldn't keep quiet about it. My friends tried to calm me down, but as my teacher approached I grew even more anxious of giving my speech. I wanted to skip my speech, but my fear of failure overpowered me. My teacher gave me some bullshit advice and that she'd base me purely on my own abilities and ushered me to the front of the class. I was so embarrassed about crying so much, but I still hadn't been able to stop. I stood in front of the class, shaking all over, for several minutes and muttered repeatedly, "Give me a few minutes." to the class. Eventually, I was forced to start and began to quietly give my speech, trying to wipe away the tears. I started crying as soon as I sat down again, fearful of getting a horrible grade. I had wanted to read off my speech as an attempt to calm my nerves, but my teacher had declined. That's probably the worst my fear of public speaking has been in a while. By the way, I got a 65% on my speech. She's making me do it again.
