I'm not formally diagnosed with anything, but I would just like to share my experiences anxiety.
1) I used to get very bad stage fright. Like my heart would start to race, my breathing would get shallow, my hands would start to shake, and my vision would white out. That's literally the worst when you're playing a solo on stage on a wind instrument. I've mostly gotten over the worst parts of that stage fright... several disaster performances later... Just as a protip: if anyone comes to you seeking advice about their stage fright / any kind of anxiety, don't tell them that "You're too worried about what other people think about you. No one cares. Not everything is about you" (literally what my orchestra director told me. Fuck him). The last thing someone with anxiety wants to hear is that it's all their fault because they are just too selfish. That's not even CLOSE to what is happening.

I have two big phobias: bridges, and daddy long legs. I would like to say that the idea of that bridge actually made me start to panic and almost cry, and that's from watching a cartoon. I cannot look over the edge of a bridge if I am forced to cross it. I will always go a longer way if possible to avoid a bridge. I specifically hate those that cars cross (as cars are heavy and increase my fear that they will collapse) and those with overhead beams. In regards to daddy longs legs the phobia is actually more extreme. While I have coping methods for bridges, such as imaging there is no gap underneath, I do not with flying daddy long legs. When one is outside I often scream and run. If I find myself trapped with one, such as in the house or when one got stuck in my dogs tail, I cry, panic, and beg for help. I refused to sleep in my room one night because one got in and instead went in the living room. Crying and shaking myself to sleep. I only say all this because if anyone takes the time to read it they may understand phobias better.

There is also a big difference between having a genetic anxiety disorder, and having one caused by an event.

People born with GAD for example, will never be able to "cure" it. We instead have to learn how to cope with it, which may require being on medication indefinitely (although therapy has proven to be very effective at learning techniques to calm yourself)

People who develop an anxiety disorder, such as PTSD may be able to get over it through therapy. However not all do.

People who are anxious before tests, or while driving on slippery roads are normal.

People who cannot leave the home, even to go to therapy, or the doctor, or school, or work, probably have a disorder.

Panic attacks are also extremely misunderstood. A low-key panic attack will be like shown in the video, chest pains, and hyperventilation.

A full blown panic attack causes your body to seize up (similar to a stroke), and hyperventilation to the point of passing out. A tell-tale sign is numbness and tingling in all of your extremities, due to both a surge of adrenaline and your hyperventilating.

Tip for those who have an anxiety disorder/suffer from panic attacks: Breathing is key! I know that this is much easier said than done but it is very important to try to master this technique because it is very helpful in stopping panic attacks in their tracks. The timing that works best for most people are 3 seconds of inhaling followed by 4-5 seconds of exhaling. It is easiest to do this when a clock is within sight because you can physically see the time pass (making it easy to calculate rather than overestimating). I hope this helps! Best to luck to all of you.

I do wish people would take this disorder more seriously. Many act like it's not a big deal and that us OCD  sufferers can easily stop. It's a slow crippling lifelong disorder, and even if you do get help in some ways it will still always be a part of you. I just wish people would realize that OCD is not just counting or washing hands or being near, sure those are some of the compulsions but those are the tip of the ice berg for many of us. Many of the obsessions and compulsions we have are difficult and very odd and do not make any sense. I have to pet the wall with my hand in a certain way until it feels right...or I have to fluff my pillow till I feel like it feels okay for me to sleep..this may take up to an hour and I'm left feeling exhausted. That's just a couple of them and I know you OCD pals can relate. Also the intrusive thoughts and worrying aren't all that fun either. But at the end of the day, I try to repeat to myself "I have OCD but OCD doesn't have me"

I've had a theory that each specific phobia was genetic for awhile. Some would be obvious, like Pyrophobia (the fear of fire). Our ancestors who had an instinctive fear of fire would obviously be more likely to survive and pass on the genes of said phobia to future generations. Others wouldn't be so obvious like Atelophobia (the fear of not being good enough or imperfection), which could be interpreted as a natural instinct to to not mess up because that might lead to your death by your companions in the ancient past, and those who survived passed on that gene to future generations. It was always just a theory, and if there was an ethical way to test it I would.

This description of OCD is so cliche. OCD is not just compulsive cleaning, hand washing, and checking appliances. Some of us do not have those specific symptoms. For me, it's obsessive fact checking, having to know the minute details about something, and not being able to pull myself away from something that sucks me in. It can also mean becoming obsessed with someone or something from the past. This is how I deal with anxiety, pain, and unresolved issues. For example, a credit card company tried to sue me a few years ago. I threw myself into legal studies for weeks and submitted over 300 pages of rebuttals. I won the case. The problem was, I couldn't break away from the topic or think about anything else during that time.

Unfortunatley, people do make jokes about hepititus and other physical disorders. Some are deeply rooted in our language. Calling somebody a "Spaz" refers to spasmatics with muscle control problems. "Dumb" of course refers to somebody who can't speak. And jokes about STDs and sexual dysfunctions are considered funny, in an "edgy" kind of way, as they have been since God knows when..

I am diagnosed with mild Tourettes. It started when I was 7-8 and has been with me throughout my teens and early twenties now. It has been agonizing. Luckily my vocal ones ( emphasizing D sounds in words etc. The common misconception of swearing is EXTREMELY rare to have) have almost dissapeared entirely and after years of practise I can now somewhat hide my facial tics. My tics happen in bouts. They are extremely intense for about 3-4 weeks and then dissipate almost entirely for a month and then the cycle repeats. 
"Why don't you just.. not?" has been a CONSTANT question from people throughout my childhood and the depression of not knowing how to express my INTENSE need to take action on my compulsion have really fucked up parts of my life. But it is just that. A part of my life. The thing to come to grips with when it comes to Mental disorders is that it doesn't define you. You are SO SO SO much more than that. 

I don't really know why I felt the urge to share, but meh.. The void of the internet is therapeutic, I guess. Peace.

Dear apostles, I want you to know joy.  

Eternal joy will be yours in heaven, of course, but I want you to know joy now, during your time of service. If you do as I say, as I am asking you, this heavenly joy will become more and more available to you and you will share this joy more and more freely. You will be a true representative of heaven in your joy and others will be attracted to the heaven that you represent. 

I want you to believe Me when I tell you that you can trust Me. If you could not trust Me, dear apostles, why would you continue to follow Me? The answer is that you can trust Me, of course, or you would fall away as others have fallen away. You do trust Me. You rely on Me and you are safe with Me. You have made a wise decision by putting yourself into My care. It is always the best decision to rely on the One who loves you perfectly and holds, in His heart, the perfect plan for your time on earth. 

Why would you let fear diminish your joy? Why would you let anxiety for yourself or others eradicate the joy that is available to you in the present moment? My dearest apostles, you live in the present, not the future. If the present is difficult, I am there. If the future becomes difficult, I will be there, too. You will not be abandoned and your loved ones will not be abandoned. Ultimately, the greater the trust in Me, the greater the joy in each moment. I want you to abandon fear. I want you to cast yourself into the providence that surrounds you. Fear is a snare for you or I would not treat it so seriously. 

Ask Me now for greater trust and I will give it to you. Ask Me now for greater joy and I will give that to you, also. It is important that others see in you an accurate reflection of the graces heaven makes available to apostles. Do not hide these graces away. Let these graces flow out from you to those around you. Share what is good, dear apostles, not what is bad. Share what comes from Me and you will help to draw others back into our family. I am telling you that I have greater graces available to you so make your Jesus happy and ask for these graces. You will be blessed with all that you need and joy will be yours. Be at peace. I will never abandon you.

I've been experiencing a lot of anxiety for over a year now.  I've experience the physical result of anxiety such as chest pain, raising heart rate, and difficulty breathing.  The worst was a couple of months ago when I bought a new car and it lasted over a month.  I get anxiety when I have to drive and when I buy something expensive.  The reason why I have anxiety over driving is because of two car accident that happen 2 or 3 years ago and both time, it was caused by a careless driver.  Both situation the other driver tried to blame me or try to avoid fault.  Although I won the first accident case and agreed to not get the insurance involve in the second because there weren't any noticeable damage, I still get frustrated that there are too many close call everyday I drive.  I recently bought  a new car and it made my anxiety even worst. When I get out of my car, I always check for scratches and dents religiously and document all dents and scratches, it always seem like people are stopping too close to my rear or driving too close to the side of my car.  I wish I was driving a clunker, then this anxiety would all go away when I'm driving.

In regard to buying expensive thing like a new car, I've always document all the tiny deflects and I get worry that what I bought is deflective or will become defective.  The fear of paying for what I'm not getting or buyer remorse, I guess is what causing my anxiety. 

All of these things are making living a hell.  Everyday I fear going out of my house because of driving.  Aside from the time I do have to drive, like to get to work, I avoid driving and start walking to buy things like food.  When I buy a high ticket item, I always document every aspect of it, I even take pictures as to compare it to something I may have caused like scratches and stuff.

I not sure why I'm like this, it wasn't always like this.  I guess when I was younger, I always get a hand me down and used stuff that always had something wrong which didn't bug me at the time.  But now, I work very hard for my money and when I buy something, I expect to be fully satisfied with what I bought and I'm afraid of damaging or degrading the things I buy.  So I'm constantly testing and comparing these things I bought with other people who bought the same things to make sure the one I bought is not deflective.  I like to think that what I bought will last me forever. 

Anyway, that's my experience with anxiety.  It just seem like our lives would be easier if our lives weren't surrounded by materialist needs.

It upset me when people joked around saying, you don't have OCD your room is to messy, or your desk is a mess. My OCD is more psychological, I would have thoughts in my head that if a door was left open something bad would happen to my family, or if a tap was running someone would get hurt. Taps were a big one for me, I would be laying in bed for almost half an hour trying to sleep, when I would think a tap was running, I would have to run to the bathroom and hold the taps for twenty seconds to make sure they were off, and walk in and out of the room 7 times to be sure they were off, i could do this 8 times a night sometimes. It honestly drives me crazy and angers me so much when people say OCD is something you can just get over!

I think the picture of OCD you are trying to present is a little bit biased.
As you correctly stated, OCD is characterized by unwanted and repetitive thoughts and only occassionally turns into visible problems and urges to perform some sort of a ritual, however, you only talk about the compulsions from there on. In fact, the obsessive part of OCD is often considered the worse one, in fact, the purely obsessive OCD is considered the worst form of OCD by many.
It can go from something as simple as having a song stuck in your head for the day, to something as unbelievable as imagining of raping your whole family and then killing them with a chainsaw. The worst part of this is, the people, who do not know they have this kind of a problem, often consider themselves sick and start to loath themselves, constantly fearing they are some sort of a deviant...

I love the way you defined anxiety disorders. I developed an anxiety disorder in 1st grade but once in 7th grade, I literally could leave my bedroom. I'm not over exaggerating when I say I never left my bedroom. I felt as if I was in a dream, it was because when a panic attack came on my brain tried too hard to stop it from continuing by making me feel as if nothing was real, which made me panic more, not knowing wether I was sleeping or this was real life. I missed all of my 7th and 8th grade years because we had no idea it was anxiety so I spent 2 years straight in and out of hospitals trying to figure out why I was feeling this way and we got every blood test, CAT scans we could think of. When I was diagnosed with an anxiety disorder I had already run away from it so much that I wasn't used to being out of the comfort of my bedroom. Not even sitting at my dinner table was ok. I couldn't do it. When I told me parents I was afraid to go to school again because I was afraid I was going to panic over a panic attack they couldn't understand it. They didn't understand what was wrong with me, it's been 6months since I started getting back into real life and I'm even traveling to Cambodia on a service trip! A lot of young people seem to be coming here saying they have disorders that were most likely self diagnosed, so just getting one important thing out of the way:

DO NOT SELF DIAGNOSE, EVER. I cannot overstate this enough. Your own point of view is VERY misleading, it's easy to unconsciously do things to fit certain labels so you feel better.

NO ONE on the internet can give you a reliable diagnosis. If you think you have something you can visit a professional and you'll figure it out together with time.

Thinking you can self-diagnose can lead you to adopting incorrect labels, which can get you thinking you have a problem you don't (AND you'll start acting like you actually HAVE something you don't have, thus REINFORCING the idea that you have a problem when you don't in a negative feedback loop), or even worse, it can get you thinking you have a problem when in reality you actually DO HAVE a problem, but something else entirely.

This happened to me and I saw it happen to many others. Do. Not. Self. Diagnose.

This comment is for those who would like to know how I cured myself of OCD without professional help. Hank does an "okay" job describing OCD and I put that in quotations because he is obviously smart and reads a-lot. Everything sounds like it came out of a text book. Unless you've personally experienced any type of disorder first hand you will never be able to comprehend, help, or explain it in it's truest form. Before I had OCD I was fascinated with psychology so when OCD came over me apart of me was actually intrigued with how my brain obsessed over one "thought" and "why" so I pretty much saw myself as an experiment instead of getting caught up in fear. Now, it didn't start off that way. I always struggled with anxiety due to irrational fears and after my life came crashing down in November of 2013 I developed OCD. I was scared out of my mind because the rational side of me couldn't comprehend why I would obsess over something so stupid. Not knowing it was OCD at first made it worse because all my "focus" was revolved around my "thoughts" and symptoms. The main struggle with OCD is "focus" because unless you divert your attention elsewhere you cannot cure OCD. The only reason it's so hard to do that is because of the importance you've given that one single thought which has automatically triggered a negative sensation in your body "anxiety" therefore your brain thinks something is wrong with that thought and you obsess over it. It's as if every time you think of it an alarm is set off in your brain. The more you think about it or anything related to it period will only prolong your OCD. After 2 months of suffering and rushing thoughts, hoping it would go away I realized something was seriously wrong. I then came to realize I had developed OCD and read that curing it was only possible with professional help using coginitive behavioral therapy and ERP. I don't like to believe everything I read so I decided to learn as much as I could about OCD and the brain. I studied endlessly, persistently, day in and day out for 2 more months and when I had finally wrapped my head around the whole ordeal I realized that it isn't all that scary and I wasn't going to let this get the best of me. I was going to cure myself and within the next two months of practicing mindful awareness, patience, and perseverance I was free from OCD. It wasn't easy, but nothing in life is easy and if you want something you have to be willing to fight for it, work day and night for it, you would be surprised what you can accomplish when you set your mind to something. At first I struggled but I kept at it and eventually it stuck. Never let anyone tell you that you can't do something, If I can cure myself on my own and it's been a year since then... anyone can. I didn't get into much detail but if anyone is in desperate need of help feel free to message me. Thank you.

I just want to point out that anxiety disorders can also have physical impact on the body. It can make you feel nauseous, dizzy, induce vomiting or cause diarrhea. If you have anxiety and are also feeling ill constantly, your anxiety might be to blame! I was sick everyday for 4 years, and could barely eat or attend school. After numerous medical tests one doctor made the connection between my anxiety and my feeling nauseous, and since I've been on medications I'm almost back to feeling normal! Other people who have anxiety disorders that I've talked too have had similar problems, so I hope this helps you guys!

I can get a feeling of discomfort if I don't touch something "correctly" (often doors/handles, light switches, railings) and I feel the need to try again a few times until it feels "right". I can fight the urge but I come away with a few nervous thoughts ("what if this makes me have a bad day?", "could this cause my friend to die?") which dissipate within a few minutes. This happens multiple times per day, but I don't feel that my life is adversely affected by it. Is this anxiety-related or some kind of 'mild' OCD? Is it just a quirk? I think it could have something to do with the anticonvulsant drug I've been on for three years, since 'personality changes' was a possible side effect; maybe it's just more common than I think. [p.s. I apologize if my terminology is poor, I don't mean to make light of anyone having a distressful or dysfunctional disorder and I can't imagine the strength one must have do deal with the things discussed in this lesson.]

I'm disappointed that the links between ADHD and Tourettes Syndrome (which are more motor-based manifestations of the same  disorder that OCD stems from) and the frequency in co-morbidity with varying severity wasn't addressed... It's been found that while OCD seems to be a conscious compulsion, there are also reflexive compulsions that tend to be even further abstracted, like in the automatic brain/subconscious mind that was discussed in the 8th video on Consciousness.

It's basically been theorized that all three are likely the result of a neurological short circuit that causes the unconscious mind to leak into the conscious to varying degrees- OCD is when the associations and conditions of the unconscious leak into the conscious and try to compel behaviors, Tourettes is when those selfsame associations leak almost directly into the reflexes/autonomic nervous system, and ADHD is when the unconscious mind's processes end up showing up unfiltered in the conscious mind whenever the conscious mind is not actively processing new stimulus. All of them seem to be neurologically related to varying degrees, and I'm surprised you didn't bring that up.

The more compulsions you do, the worse your OCD will get. When you do a compulsion, your mind sees it as a signal that something really is wrong and sends you more thoughts. The mind can't tell a difference between a real thought and an OCD thought in order to determine whether to send you more thoughts or not. The only way it can tell is by your actions. If you act scared and give into compulsive actions, the mind views this as if you are trying to protect yourself from a real problem and "reminds" you more and more of this problem. In order to break the cycle you need to stop following compulsions. Please note that compulsions can be rituals or it can be mental only, such as when you only think about something over and over again. By stopping the compulsions you stop the cycle of OCD!

Thank you for making this video, Hank.  My family suffers from a range of anxiety disorders, complete with formal clinical diagnoses.  It's hard, sometimes, even for me to realize when my thoughts or behaviors are manifestations of social anxiety, OCD, and/or depression until I'm deep into it or after the fact.  My OCD diagnosis does include some of the things people might joke about (sorting m&m's before eating them in descending order by count of each color) and those things are mild.  But I'm also prone to addiction (itself often described as compulsive behavior), checking and counting/calculating, and to a lesser degree every category of OCD except obsessive cleanliness (go figure).  I guess my point, if there is one to be made here, is that if you are someone who people joke about having OCD or anxiety or any other mental illness, it might be worth paying some attention.  Those little tells are more often than not nothing more than personality quirks.  But sometimes Hollywood stereotyped OCD can be a sign of something deeper.  And OCD and other anxiety disorders are much easier to cope with if you identify them early and seek help and/or treatment.

I have been diagnosed with OCD by both a certified therapist and a medical doctor. In many cases OCD sufferers are found to create a lack of the enzyme that absorbs and processes folic acid. This enzyme is called L-methyl Folate. If taken daily in pill form, this can seriously decrease the symptoms  of OCD and eventually take it away all together. Because L-methyl Folate isn't a pharmaceutical drug with weird side effects, and is in fact a vitamin that people take for health benefits who don't even have OCD, it's a better way to go for anyone dealing with this absolutely curable physical illness. Please, if you have OCD or know anyone with debilitating or severe OCD, share this info with them and it will get better. This vitamin had helped me a whole lot.

While it sucks that people trivialize mental disorders, the first point Hank made is actually a good explanation (though not justification) into why this happens: Many mental disorders consitute an imbalance or extreme form of something otherwise normal, e.g. anxiety or sadness. Hence, it is difficult for healthy people to understand or detect how or when something moves beyond the threshold of normal into "disorder" territory. That simply doesn't happen with a lot of physiological illnesses. Nobody says, "Well, I mean, we all got a little cancer/HIV", because that is something you either have or don't. It's not a point on a scale like with mental traits.

I was diagnosed with Generalized Anxiety Disorder five years ago. Luckily, I have been able to overcome the intrusive, detrimental side of it. I absolutely love the way Hank touches on not being able to identify the source of your anxiety, because that was (and, sometimes, continues to be) the world I live(d) in. Genetically, I am pre-disposed to mental illness. My father has always been a suffering man, my mother tells me. Growing up, I remember crying, scared out of my mind as early as 9 years old. When my mom would ask why, I told her that I didn't know. This only prompted her to persistently (and sometimes angrily) ask again, even though I was being completely honest. When my anxiety got really bad, there were very few moments of comfort in my life. I didn't have a safe place, because I was constantly on edge no matter where I went or what I did. I never felt any relief from my anxiety which, ultimately, made recovering seem hopeless. After a few rounds of medication, some serious re-evaluation, and self-care, I beat what I thought would be the death of me.

For some profoundly strange reason, a lot of the comments below seem to be from people who are "proud" to have Anxiety Disorder. A lot of it no doubt stems from people's desire to be edgy and cool and dark or whatever. Personally, that sort of thing annoys the hell out of me. If you met me, you'd never think anything was mentally unbalanced about me; those who know me(mostly family as I have...well, no friends) know I'm intelligent creative and a good person. But....for years now(5 years maybe?) I've basically lived within my apartment 24/7. I leave maybe once every 3 days, only to get something from the convenience store a block away. That's IT.

When I'm out in public...there's something horribly oppressive about it. Society is LOUD and BRIGHT and aggressive and harsh and abrasive. When I'm home, I feel ok...sometimes even quite happy. But, I find people and public life to be overwhelmingly hostile. You know when people will say something really mean and judgmental, and then follow it up with, "What?? I'm just bein' honest. Just bein' real." Well, that's what ALL of public society feels like to me. Just a giant mean place devoid of intelligence, compassion, creativity, and warmth.

However, because of this, I've lost many jobs...and cannot leave my apartment to find a job. The few times I've tried, I've had horrible panic attacks. I know it hurts my parents greatly...and they try to help. It truly sucks. I WANT to be a part of society...I don't want to die a recluse, but, I'm not sure how to take the first step and do what to me feels like jumping into a bath of acid.

I will say, marijuana helps a LOT....I mean a huge huge amount. Sadly, it's illegal where I live(TN) and I can barely come by it. If only I had that whenever I needed it, my life would utterly transform. It calms me, focuses me, allows me to see the good in life, and feel ok in my own skin in public. But no, the government won't ALLOW me that....which I find utterly evil. It disgusts me that I'm barred from using something that would transform my life because a handful of Senators deem it unworthy of Americans or something. Yet another reason why I find society gross and harsh and worth avoiding.

Is there anyone else who can relate? I've lived like this for 5 years or so now. I'm 31...and I simply can't waste my life anymore. I feel I've got too much potential to be couped-up inside forever. Yes, I feel safe and often happy here....but I don't want to do this forever. And yes.....I've gone to doctors, been prescribed meds, done therapy, etc etc etc. The ONLY thing that's ever helped is marijuana. But, when I mentioned that to a doctor, you know what his reaction was? "Oh...so you have a drug problem too? Here, I'll prescribe you some Xanax; it'll help." I almost didn't know what to say...I thought he was joking. Plus, marijuana isn't physically addictive and has zero negative side effects(for me)...quite unlike the Rx fucking narcotics I've been prescribed in the past. It angers me beyond words how strangers will vote to keep it illegal, unaware of the harm they perpetrate. It's sickening.

Sigh.... sorry for the long post. Can anyone relate? Sometimes I feel utterly ashamed of what I've become, but I have to believe I'm not alone....

The problem with understanding people who suffer from mental conditions is that we tend to look at them objectively. We look at their symptoms and behaviour, but we struggle to have an true understanding of what they are truly going through. Because we don't have their subjective involvement into these conditions. For example we might say those who suffer from an anxiety disorder might get severe panic attacks, but it's impossible for a "normal" person, who has never had an panic attack to such a degree, to put themselves into the shoes of someone who goes through such a condition.

Many of the things described in this video as not OCD or not an anxiety disorder, are part of developing an anxiety disorder. Full-blown OCD doesn't just fall from the sky one day. I spent more than a decade working up to the point where I was scalding my hands to be certain they were clean. Now I know that's the common trajectory for developing many mental health issues--every part of my life was full of compulsions and things completely fell apart before I finally went to get help. That's not a healthy way to take care of your mental or physical health.

Anxiety disorders progress gradually, although we're rarely aware of them at the time because we have reasons, we think we need our compulsions, they help us, they relieve anxiety, and there are videos like this that take an illness-first approach, that insist you're not sick enough so you need to get sicker before you have a "real" issue. That's not the case. We've made the shift to preventative, proactive care when it comes to physical health, but culturally, our approach to mental health lags behind. Saying you don't have an anxiety disorder until you're unable to leave your house is like saying you don't have heart disease until you the paramedics are giving you CPR after you've had a massive heart attack. 

With mental health, as with physical health, it's highly advisable to not wait until things get that bad.

We all have mental health and we're all doing things everyday to improve, maintain, or worsen our mental health. It is not helpful to wait until things get so bad that your world is falling apart and your harming yourself. There are many opportunities to deal with anxiety disorders before things get that bad and there is an amazing range of effective ways to recover fully from an anxiety disorder so you can do things you want to do in life and go the places you want to go, rather than constantly reacting to fears and uncertainties. But just like with physical health, the earlier you start taking care of your mental health, the better.

I've had OCD in the past, and I can safely say that it is no laughing matter. I was diagnosed with it when I was 10. People used to tell me to "stop being a pussy" or "be a man" which if they had the slightest clue what it was like, wouldn't have said those things. OCD is can be described as having a feeling of extreme anxiety, which makes the individual literally feel as those completing the task OCD is warning against impossible. In my case, I used to have to wash my hands every I touched something which I deemed "Dirty", Not doing so would case a horrible feeling that I would do anything to get rid of. I visited multiple psychiatrists, who were all but useless. In the end, around age 16, the only reason I got over it was because I decided not to live my life that way anymore. I would on purposely touch "dirty" things, such as money, and not wash my hands. It was one of the hardest challenges I have faced in my life, but I beat it.

People who gossip, "Oh, he must have OCD" are ignorant fools. Psychiatrists aren't very useful because they base their analyzes on a text book definition of OCD, the only thing they gave me was drugs (because that fixes everything). I have heard rumors that only rich/spoiled kids get OCD, which is entirely not true.

So my advice, facing OCD is no easy challenge, but the only cure is if you choose to face it. No one can force you to face or  beat it, just know that in the end you will be better off without it.

I have OCD and I just wanted to let anyone who has the disorder or believes they have it that you might be able to be helped without medication and that CBT (cognitive behavioral therapy) is a great option. A year ago, I could not go half a minute without getting the intense urge to complete some ritual (usually tapping/mental). I didn't realize it at the time because I was more caught up in the embarrassment and annoyance of these rituals, and as distressed as I was I was coping, but that meant that I was literally living in a constant nightmare of worry. I've been pretty much completely out of therapy for three months now (used to go like once a week) and although I had my ups and downs while I was going through CBT, I not only hardly do rituals but I hardly ever get the urge... and when I do, it's usually easy to shake off by going through what I've learned in therapy. I almost actually forgot until I saw this video that I even have OCD. I still suffer moderately with anxiety that feels more like GAD (but I haven't seen anyone about it so..) but I can say emphatically that going through therapy is not a waste of time. I was pretty skeptical of it when I first started because I didn't think I could even make a dent in my OCD without medication,  but now I can say confidently that it has been one of the best choices I've made for myself.

Yeah, social anxiety is the worst and it only gets worse as the result of avoidance behavior. For most my adolescence, and young adult life, I've had an unhealthy fear of social interaction. I just feel awkward, and uneasy around people. I have a strong distaste for small talk, probably because I am bad at it. Small talk is a bit pretentious, and superficial. I like to engage in serious, deep philosophical conversation about subjects I am passionate about. But 90 percent of the time, it never gets past 'what's your favorite color' range. My advice to those that suffer social anxiety is to not avoid it. I used to work retail and I held a position that was the point of contact for the customer. It always made me really uneasy, and gave me bad anxiety, but it made me confront my anxiety. Unknowingly, it was therapeutic. In college, I would give speeches in front of the class and did other forms of public speaking. It helped me greatly, forcing myself to interact with others. I've since left retail, about 7 years, and I have regressed to the point I can't even stand in front of people. Best regards to those that suffer from social anxiety, you aren't alone.

I've been diagnosed with social anxiety disorder and depression. I've been introverted and anxious my entire life, but it never really became a problem until the age of eleven or so. I started to come up with coping mechanisms and tricks to get by; little things like planning for the next situation (where to look when talking to someone, is the door push or pull, cross or uncross my arms, sit or stand, how many people in the room, how long will I be there, what will I need, who do I know there, what will be required of me, the amount of social interaction, will I be the center of attention, should I smile or look serious, how do I get out of this situation if I need to, etc.), creating a personality for a situation (mirroring others' personalities, actions and behaviors mostly, sometimes outright lying and acting), and some misc. compulsive behaviors to calm myself down (mostly counting, controlling my breathing and doing things with my hands; things that wouldn't be noticed by others or bring attention to me). I have no friends (I outright prefer NOT to have friends), I distance myself from others (people at work hardly know me, I avoid my neighbors/people I see on a daily basis, etc.) and being around people - even when not interacting with them - is exhausting and stressful. My brain is constantly abuzz with thoughts like "look away, you're staring too long" and "breath in, breath out; from the diaphragm not the chest, don't let them see you". Because of this inner dialogue to keep me functional in the real world, it can be difficult for me to do much else than just that: function. I am always tense and closed in, ready for anything at any moment. My heart races, my head is pounding and I'm sweating. When I'm finally alone or around a single person that I can trust and feel comfortable around, it is like the world get quiet. I can breathe again and my mind is at ease. It is a beautiful feeling, but a very lonely one. No matter how many times I snuggle my dog or talk to myself, I will always be friendless and isolated. I'm not shy and I do get lonely. I don't hate people and I have things to say. Having social anxiety, for me, is very debilitating on my social life (obviously), work life (promotions are hard if no one knows you), school life (I'm afraid to go to college; what if I can't handle it?), and inner life. Having social anxiety can cause feelings of low self esteem, contributes to depression and loneliness. On the one hand, I want to be alone, but on the other hand, I miss people. I want to know them. I meet people that I want to interact with and get to know, but I am too afraid to risk it. What if I can't handle it? What if they don't understand? What if they reject me? What if I turn out to NOT like them, how do I get rid of them without being rude? How do I tell people that I miss them and care about them.... but I don't want to see them, talk to them or spend time with them? One begins to question if it is even possible to truly connect with others with those kind of limitations. I don't expect people who don't have social anxiety disorder to understand, and I really don't want them to, on some level. I kind of wish it was this big secret I could keep so I could keep acting normal forever.

I'm not sure if that is an accurate description of SAD (pffft, that minimalism)  for everyone, but that has been my experience.

Thank you. Thank you. Thank you! (For making this video.) I was diagnosed with GAD 8 years ago with the additional diagnosis of a panic disorder a year later after a hospitalization. And to the people making jokes and trying to self diagnose in the comments, please stop. If you honestly believe you have a problem, seek help for it, because if you do have any one of these disorders they can destroy your life. They've made university life, and life in general, a major struggle for me. GAD manifests itself in debilitating migraines and the constant need for me to pick or scratch at my skin. Panic attacks come when I least expect them, on the subway or in the middle of class, when something troubling, such as just the possibility of missing a deadline, creeps into my mind. So please, get help or stop making light of this.

I used to make jokes about OCD and talk about it lightly, until I got it myself and realised it was much more serious than I'd thought. I was hoping for their support but because of this relaxed attitude so many people have about OCD, they just told me there was nothing wrong with me when I was actually struggling a lot. Please do not use this as an invitation to diagnose other people.  If someone tells you they are OCD don't try and correct them because they may actually have the condition and you're making them feel ashamed for admitting their illness.  A lot of people are really good at hiding their obsessive behaviors from friends and even family, and the last thing they need is to feel invalidated by those close to them because their mom watched a video online or something.

Let's just do our best to be empathetic.  If someone hurts our feelings throwing around a condition understand it comes from a childlike ignorance and immaturity.  If someone says they're "kind of bipolar" don't call them out on it but understand that may be their way of telling you they actually are bipolar (but don't want you to think they're crazy so they downplay it).  You just never know what someone else's story is, I guess is all i'm saying.

My anxiety started when I started getting sudden pains and dizziness. I'm young (Still in highschool) so it was really weird to me that I kept getting sharp chest pains and feeling dizzy out of no where. So I started basically diagnosing myself with all sorts of things, like I was having a heart attack, or that my blood veins were "deformed". At one point I questioned if I was just dead and it was like, the afterlife. I made my parents take my to the doctors and I made sure I ruled out every possible thing that could be wrong. But even when I sat right there and watched the heart monitor or saw the results of my tests as healthy, I was still sure that I had something wrong with me. At one point they thought I had a blood clot, and I was so happy because I thought "Finally they found what was wrong and this'll all end." But I was upset when I didn't actually have one, which really sounds weird. I also had this "dizziness" that made things not even seem real, and I really thought people were saying scripts just to mess with me. The panic attacks were awful too, and I still have "anxiety" about certain things I guess. For example, I had a panic attack while taking a bath, so I would bathe less frequently, which made me feel even worse. And I still feel a little anxious when I'm in the bathtub. The panic attacks just led me in loops too, because I would have one when I thought something was wrong, or something hurt, and panic attacks just made me hurt even more. Eventually I didn't want to sleep because my brain created nightmares about what I was going through in real life. I couldn't even sleep and be in peace. Then I just didn't want to wake up and didn't really care if I died anymore. And at the same time I wanted to live so badly. Then people called me a hypochondriac for being so worried about my health, and a druggy for being on anxiety/depression medication. So seeing like, things about meth or weed (I'm in Colorado where weed is legal too) really freaked me out for a while, and I wouldn't/still don't take simple things like cough drops.

TL;DR: Anxiety really sucks, and doesn't just go away. And to anyone out there dealing with anxiety, especially at a young age, just know that it'll get better. You won't be like this forever, and you aren't the only one with it. Some things might change about you, but with willpower, you can change those things back. Unless those changes are for the better of course. And also, don't feel bad about taking medication to help you get through something. If it helps you, it helps you, and it helps you get through another day. Just make sure its the right thing for you, and if you feel uncomfortable with it, then talk to a doctor to get you off of it.

I have arachnophobia (phobia of spiders), and recently I've found a way to describe the feeling of being confronted with a spider to people without this problem. When confronted with most of my fears, for example I'm not fond of heights, I'll be afraid, but eventually I'll be able to sort of push through it or use logic to calm myself down so I can, for example, ride a zip-line. But if I'm in a situation where I have to be near a spider and say, move it or something, then as much as I tell myself that there's nothing to be scared of and I'm bigger than it and it can't hurt me and most spiders aren't really dangerous anyways, it doesn't matter. I know it's ridiculous for me to be that afraid, but I just can't bring myself to grab a stick and move the spider, or even get near it. And that makes it even worse because along with the fear and the physical manifestations of it (rapid heartbeat, goosebumps, feeling itchy all over, etc.), there's all this frustration that I can't do this seemingly simple task, and embarrassment when I have to ask for help. And all of this compounds to make me feel even more anxious and unhappy and it's just not good. Idk if other people feel the same way, but it's the best way I've found to describe my personal experiences.

In the Netherlands it is quite normal to make jokes or casual references or tease buddies with physical illnesses. In fact, the Dutch word for teasing is "plagen," which literally translates in "to plague." Cancer, typhus, cholera, tuberculosis, bubonic plague and smallpox are all common swear words. If someone is to lazy to pick something up, we'll say "You don't have leprosy or do you?"
But even in English people will say that someone or something is "lame" or "dumb" or say "are you blind or something?"

A lot of the people I know who say they have "mild" OCD don't really have much difficulty going about their daily lives. They have compulsions, sure, but they only involve habitual cleaning, where they might take the same cleaning route every time they clean, or have to touch a doorknob twice before opening the door. Meanwhile, people who actually have milder forms of OCD generally have to be symmetrical, often having to touch both of their index fingers to the sides of their desks the same amount of times to help get passed the uncomfortable feeling. Oddly enough, most times I hear people misuse the term "OCD" is when they're referring to themselves.

I have GAD and Panic Disorder, and it's awful that people don't understand how physically exhausting it is to be nervous 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. It always was very difficult to explain to people who do not suffer from anxiety disorder, what it is like. I remember I told others about the panic attacks, and they would tell me I was overreacting. I can't blame them for not understanding, they never where in that situation. And honestly, at first, I didn't even understand what the heck was going on in my head.
Anyways, my tips for everyone: Don't self-medicate, it will only make things worse. Find a creative outlet, it can work very therapeutic. Do some research on this topic, trying to understand is important to deal with it. Try and realize that panic attacks don't last forever, and you will not lose your mind. And when you do feel anxious/ have an attack, just keep focusing on something happy/cute, and nothing else.

So.. I count the steps, especially at places I go less frequent. On places where I go daily I do not count always, just about every second day or so and I do various countings, like the 60 steps are 4 x 15 steps with a little "plattform" between them. Sometimes I cound just up to 15 and then from 0 again, sometimes to 60, sometimes in base 8 (I know I am weird), you get the picture.

Also when walking on tiled floors I avoid stepping on the edges and adjust my step size to match the size of the tiles. If the tiles are too small and odd shaped (like on the paving on the train plattform I walk on every day) I search for repeating patterns on which I prefer to step. I must look crazy as the patterns make me "rotate" my foot... But again, I do not do it always, but really much more often than a normal person. In fact I have never seen anybody else doing it. I do it especially when waiting for a train and killing time, I search and walk patterns I recognize in the "patchwork" of the paving blocks. However when I need to catch the train I forget about everything and run normally, ignoring the edges. So it does not affect me that much, just when there is no hurry.

Another thing is turning corners. After every 90° turn I feel like a sprung and have to return to my original direction, this feeling fades away after a few steps. What I feel especially unpleasant is to walk a way in a shopping mall for example around a pillar when I have to take something that is just behind it and rotate 360° to get where I was, it is as if I felt a "tension" which I can release only by rotating myself standing on one spot in the opposite direction. This has become less of an issue over the years, but as a child it was very unpleasant.

I also find myself counting the number of axles of passing trains. I know that some people count the number of cars of a passing train, this is pretty normal, but I cound axles. And this is sometimes a challange as there are 2, 3, 4 and 6 axle cars in mixed freight trains. If it passes by fast I get confused sometimes. Especially the three axle cars are a challange when mixed with four axle cars that look similar. But again, I do not cound every passing train, just most of them. I feel irriatated when something blocks the train I was couning, like another train or when I am counting when sitting in a moving train and a fence abruptly stops my counting without finishing it. That is the worst and happens sometimes. While I feel discomfort I do not freak out.

So am I normal or not?

LONG ANXIETY/DEPRESSION STORY AHEAD:

i used to have an anxiety disorder (caused by depression), i didnt know what i was anxious about and the depression contributed in me not wanting to do absolutely anything. the anxiety was always there and my chest felt heavy all the time, i couldnt tell what was causing it and i kept thinking there was something wrong with my heart and lungs because of how hard it felt to breathe sometimes, as if my head was in a plastic bag. i didnt go to school or outside at all for weeks (and i skipped full on months of school for several years). it made me become a sedentary and inactive person, even tho i was very active before that, and even now that im better its hard to shake that off. i dont go out very much compared to the 'norm'. 
because of my anxiety my heart felt like it was gonna explode any moment and my brain would never ever shut up, and i started to have terrible insomnia. it got so bad that even heavy sleeping medication wouldnt put me to sleep, whenever i was awake i was barely there and i was often extremely slow and confused. i was forgetful and i cant say i knew what i was doing all the time. if i was sleeping and someone woke me up i would start crying because of how badly i needed rest, realizing i was finally asleep after hours of trying but was woken up after only a short time felt like the world had shattered. this was also one of the main reasons i would avoid school, as i couldnt fall asleep no matter how early i went to bed. thinking of the time i had to wake up and how i wasnt sleeping yet while i was laying down only led to more anxiety which made falling asleep even harder
the anxiety also led to stomach and intestine problems, and i had to call an ambulance twice for almost getting ulceras (it was SO painful). after those episodes my stomach and intestine are still very weak and now its easy for me to get terrible heart-burn or cramps for various reasons, even tho it never happened before that. at the time i also suffered from bad migraines, which the doctors i went to also linked to stress, that have since then almost completely disappeared
eventually i also started getting panic attacks where i couldnt move or breathe, and they left me so weak i thought i would pass out. thankfully it always happened at home and in my mothers car only once, i dont know what i would've done if i was in public (the shame that comes with these behaviours is also horrible, and not just panic attacks).
this time in my life was so terrible that i dont even remember what happened during certain parts of it. we went to a family vacation during a time when my condition was very bad and seeing the pictures from it i can say with absolute certainty that i do not remember that place at all, save for a few flashes

thankfully therapy and time helped me, and even though it sometimes a few episodes keep happening its usually not as bad because i learned how to deal with those situations. living with an anxiety disorder (etc.) is not easy and im so glad im out of it now, even if im always scared it will come back whenever i get that chest pain feeling. its not a battle you cant win but its very very hard

its quite upsetting seeing people laugh at those sort of disorders or use those terms as nicknames for quirky behaviour when you know what it really means. i learned to deal with people's ignorance (its hardly done with ill intentions after all) but its still somewhat hurtful that mental disorders are not considered as crippling as the physical ones, and as such are easier to belittle. i know they are very hard to relate to or understand if you didnt go through them, because they are so very personal...if you dont have or have never had a mental disorder please consider yourself very very lucky, and try to emphasize with those who have a little bit more, because trust me they are suffering

if you read this whole comment wow good job, go get yourself a treat! im sure it wasnt an easy read

Thank you Hank. Thank you so much. I'm an adult with ADD-I and probably some general anxiety and leftover ODD (Oh ADD and its co-existing conditions!) I always hear people say "I'm so ADD today." and it's disheartening. The adults at my work and friends in my life don't seem to understand how demeaning it is to have the condition that ruins your life trivialized.

I have tried explaining what it's like and I get a lot of "Oh, yea. I get distracted too, but I just get some coffee and focus hard. That seems to work. I probably have ADD but I don't need meds." Which makes me want to scream at them, but I cant.

I want to say "Oh so you have spent all morning telling yourself over and over 'don't forget the keys idiot!' chanting in your head like a mantra, only to get out to the car and realize not only have you forgot your heys but also your walet? Did you sit in your car and nearly break down because this is the 5th day in a row of doing that? Did you nearly cry because of the embarrassment of having to go back and admit you forgot your keys again? Dose it feel like the only thing people won't let you forget is that your forgetful?"

And then there are the days where people insinuate that I only got diagnosed for the meds, or that adults "Fake" it and it's just something for kids. Or the people who get onto the ADD communities and keep insisting to us that the meds aren't needed and that they can control it through diet and exercise.

So thank you and I hope to see more. If you ever need help with web design I would be happy to donate my time for this cause.

Great video! It does annoy me when people use the term OCD lightly. As someone who has been diagnosed with it at an early age and still suffers from it, I can say it takes on so many more forms than simply cleanliness or ordering things in certain ways, too! For example a symptom of mine is that I feel a severe urge to find out things that I don't know, like song lyrics I hear but can't quite understand. I'm then stricken with a terrible fear that if I don't google it and find out the lyrics RIGHT NOW then I will worry about it for the rest of my life. It seems so silly, I know, but that's what it does!  

That said, I don't mind jokes about OCD. In fact I find that it helps me feel easier about the fact that I have it.

My parents would always blame me for always losing or breaking my stuff, even though i didn't mean it. I know that it's there but my brain mixes me up by imagining that it will disappear the next minute (╥ω╥`) I just now learnt about OCD, but if i told my parents, they'll just say that i'm overthinking (╥ω╥`)

In only eighth grade I was diagnosed with GAD, Panic Disorder (As well as major depressive disorder). Due to bullying I also developed an extreme phobia of my school building and would have an awful panic attacks simply at the site of it. Unfortunately I still had to go to school no matter how many times I tried to avoid it. After many therapists and doctors, by the end of my eighth grade year I was able to go to almost all of my classes. Naturally, for 9th grade, I switched schools. Even though I do get a panic attack approximately once a month, my anxiety has become much more manageable. Only in the past couple years did my doctors notice that I also have OCD. I repeatedly wash my hands to the point of pain, I have a specific ritual that I always follow, and I pick at my skin. That specific symptom is the worst part because at every slight imperfection I default to trying to pick it off until it bleeds. Unfortunately I haven't been able to manage this as well as I had my anxiety/panic/depression.

People always joke about me being 'OCD' about things, but it's really not funny. It can be embarrassing and stressful. During exam time, my hands were sore and cracked from washing them so often and I would get stuck repeating the same actions over and over and over until they were perfect. It takes up so much time and it's hard to stop because you desperately don't want that bad thing to happen. I hate that it's not taken seriously because 'everyone is a little bit OCD', when some people spend hours each day completing rituals because they're terrified their worst fear is going to happen.

You really got my attention when you mentioned the girl who washes her hands so much, they bleed. I have been a handwasher for a long time and every winter, especially, my hands are covered in band aids so I don't bleed all over my paperwork at work. I will avoid taking say, a single potato chip, when offered because I will have to wash my hands afterwards because I can feel the grease and/or salt on the fingers that touched the chip.
In addition to this, I am what I call "a checker". I double and triple check things; that the clasp on my purse is closed, that I have the tickets with me when going to a game or concert, that doors are locked and Windows closed, that I have my keys or phone with me. I will do these things many multiple times in a day.
At least once a week, I drive away in the morning and then come back to check that I have unplugged my curling iron and locked the door. Not once, have I ever come back and found the curling iron still plugged in or the front door unlocked. But I still continue to worry about it and check it over and over again.

I really appreciate this video @***** , as a person with previously debilitating OCD.  I have one suggestion, that you could expand more on the nature of obsessions.  You still went with the stereotypical germs and stove-checking, and didn't mention that a huge percent of obsessions we suffer from have to do with hurting/killing people, doubting one's religion, and doubting one's sexuality.  Not everyone with OCD has physical compulsions--many (including me) have Pure O, meaning only obsessions.  And those with compulsions do more nonsensical rituals, including praying, chanting, counting, and hoarding.  I know you only had ten minutes, but people should know that OCD is so much more complex.

What's a bit annoying is that when I tell people I am afraid of spiders, they think that I'm just afraid of spiders. When I clarify that I have a severe phobia, they still think I'm just afraid of spiders. They don't realize how absolutely terrified I am of spiders,  because they don't realize that phobias are not like normal fears; the paralyzing feeling you get when you are submitted to your trigger is like being attacked from all sides, and you feel like throwing yourself of a bridge in that moment. You even feel that way when you're only thinking about the trigger. What's worse is that because people just don't understand, they think it's fun to prank you every now and then. Luckily, my room always seems to have spiders in it, and since I have forced myself to stay in that room (at first I only fell asleep once exhaustion set in, even though I had gotten someone to kill the spiders), I have been gradually able to reduce my anxiety in situations with small spiders. I am now able to stay calm in the presence of smaller spiders, and through meditation I have been able to reduce situations in which I work myself into a frenzy just by thinking about spiders. If there is a point to this I would say that it is if you have a phobia, do your best not to avoid that phobia (you don't have to actively seek it, just not avoid it) and after a while the phobia will become much more manageable as you aren't reinforcing the behaviour. And if that doesn't work, don't be afraid to ask for professional help.

I disagree with the notion, that avoiding circumstances necessarily makes the reasons for avoidance stronger. Many phobias have real reasons behind it, and if you are not avoiding things, that really do hurt and damage you, with the wink of "ey, if you avoid, it makes it only worse", it's actually REALLY making the avoidance behaviours worse, because of the additional negative reinforcement. Only if the reason for avoidance is decreased, fear and anxiety will really go down.

Thank you so. much. for making this. I have fairly severe OCD, and it drives me absolutely insane when somebody goes to straighten a desk or fix their handwriting and says that they're "soooo OCD". No. You have no clue what OCD is. It's not just liking things neat and tidy; it's irrational repitition and habit in every single thing you do. It's terror and lost control over your own thoughts and actions. You have absolutely no say when it comes to complusions and obsessions, and the more you struggle with it, the more anxious you get. I'd really love to see a video on personality disorders (and other what-used-to-be-Axis-II disorders before the DSM-V axed the Axis model). Just as it is annoying as heck to be called OCD for alphabetizing your movie case, I'd like to be able to say, "I have borderline personality disorder," without someone replying, "...Who are your other voices?" Or for people to recognize the difference between a shy, solitary person and a person with antisocial personality disorder. ('Cause there's a big difference. Just sayin'.) Also, you just covered, like, half the disorders in Cluster C of personality disorders anyway, so why not just work your way through the Clusters in clumps? :D

On an entirely different note, I gotta say. I'm both glad and disgruntled by the dismantling of the Axis system in the DSM-V. On one hand, it was very helpful to be able to say something like, "This person has major depression (Axis I) secondary to BPD (Axis II)," and know that, oh hey, the BPD is probably what came first in the chicken and the egg game of diagnoses, making it easier to set up treatment models. 
Then again, Axis II also carried the notion of 'probably never going away--gonna have this disorder for life', and so carried the stigma of permanence and impossible to treat. It made insurance companies shrug and say, "We're not paying for that," and doctors back away saying, "I don't wanna deal with that," so maybe it'll be better in the long run. Erasing negative stigmas attached to some disorders would be an immense step forward in mental health treatment. I guess we'll see.

I have the obsessions part of OCD - frequent negative thoughts that I have no control over, (that I'd rather not elaborate on,) and the extreme want to do certain things, even though I've no need to. But my main issues are severe anxiety, (though the net is much easier on me than any other form of interaction,) in which it is an agonizingly frightening task to do something as simple as call to make a routine doctors appointment or fill a subscription. I'm also bipolar, usually depressed but with some rage and some other mania issues that strip my discretion. (Despite my anxiety, I have, in the past, stripped in front of people to completely naked during a manic episode.) It's difficult to get treatment because it's so hard to ask for help, partly because I feel I am a hindrance, even if I know I am not. (So reassurance does little to help.) My father was abusive, and though my mother was not, she was neglectful, and tended to place my issues to the side as if they were inconveniences, so any treatment I have had has been short-lived.

I merely wanted to share my experience, perhaps to give some perspective.

Making such a big deal over the use of these terms just seems pedantic. It's like making an issue over the word "theory" when used in everyday speech because "theory" has a more rigid and specific meaning when used in a scientific context. Language is fluid and words can have multiple meanings when used in different context.

When someone says they're OCD about how they organize their sock drawer, they're not literally misdiagnosing themselves with a psychological disorder. It's a figure of speech much in the same way saying "the microwave blew up" when referring to it shorting out is not literally saying an explosion occurred within the microwave.

I want to share part of my anxiety story here and how i managed to hide it for a dangerously long time.
I was at the university at this time and every semester, my capability seemed to shrink. while I managed 8 classes in the first semester, i was not able to finish 3 in a later semester. At the time,where the illness was already part of my life, I enrolled only in classes that did not check attendance, just expected extensive projects in the end. I attended less and less seminars and in the end did not leave the house for 3 months. At that time i had a job, doing outhouse graphics for an agency - i only communicated with them via mail and telephone. Since I was able to hold down this job all the time, I thought: nothing wrong with me. see. I have a job. And hey, i AM studying. Not in the unniversiy, but at home. Maybe I am just lazy. I lied to my friends and family how my classes went and what i had done that day.
I got my friends to pick up groceries for me. I always had a good excuse, why i looked like a sleep depraved corpse. That flue i was getting over, nightshift at the agency... At the peak of my anxiety, i was afraid of everything "officy" - telephones i did not know, voices on the phone i had not talked to before, mail boxes, clocks. I redesigned everything on my computer to not look official. On the last day of that semester I had to turn in a project. I had done about half the work that others had done and came to the presentation - heavy makeup, wide clothes. I knew, that for the sake of my sanity, i had to pass at least one class - see - i am studying! The professor saw something in my work and gave me a very good grade and a very long, hard stare. I was so relieved... a feeling i had not had for months, that my body gave up. I broke down crying, completely lost it. Much later i understand, that my body knew - i could not go into the semester vacation. i could not be without contact. I am sure now, that i would not have survived. The professor then saved my life. 
She got me into her office and regularly checked on my while she took other students finals. I was just crying. When I had calmed down a little, she talked to me about her own sickness and how a psychiatrist had helped her and how she had suspected from seeing my paintings. She gave me the the address and telephone number.
I took all my courage to call that psychiatrist and got an appointment 2 months later. 2 months. But i really did not make my point on the phone, that i needed help now. I was talking to somebody i did not know. I do not know, what i did those two months. This appointment and the way, the professor saw through me when i was hiding from everybody else... I later found things i did in that time. I had hidden away everything buerocratic in that time - i found invoices and paperwork behind cuports and book cases and do not remember having put them there, i hid my student file, my tax report, i wrote an irratic message to the financial ministry, who asked for my tax report and other thing...

In the end, it took almost a year to be fully enrolled in a treatment. I got antidepressants that helped ease that permanent feeling of tension (but also caused nightmares so severe and horrible, that I had several sessions just about the induced nightmares) and a behavioral therapy, that first taught me, how to calm myself down in public and explored, how i can cope with reality again. 
I had to change my life. There was not the one thing that put me there. But many things that made my mind compulsively go into a very dark place - seeing threat where one was and over-interpreting negative things. 
To this day, I have to force myself to go out at least once a week, am usually drenched in sweat when i talked to a person on the phone I do not know (but I DO make those calls). I spot avoidance behavior and try to work against it and am always, ALWAYS honest to the people i trust and told them, how to behave, what kind of help... helps me personally.  I also know other people that have similar issues and try to help their loved ones to find the right way to deal.
It doesn't have to get that bad. As soon as you spot behaviour that takes away quality of your life to avoid something unpleasant, be really, really honest to yourself. Sometimes... it is just laziness or no time for conflict ; ) - but if it becomes a patter that you cannot get out of on your own anymore, it is not shame to ask for help. I did not see myself worthy of a professional therapist, because there are people with really bad problems out there - schizophrenia! Delusions! I did not even get, that I was afraid, i thought, i was just lazy with all this avoiding and not going shopping for myself. But... i could not participate in society. I could not "enrich" it - work a job, support others. You letting yourself be helped helps everybody.

Sorry for this essay. IT felt so good to type all that out. Thank you for this series. Thank you for explaining anxiety. While I had it, i was not aware, that this is actually a sickness. It helped, to come over it. Or at least manage it : )

Ummm The distinguishing someone who washes their clothes every day (this is a horrid example btw as it might qualify) as someone without OCD vs someone who washes their hand every 5 minutes as having OCD is wrong and it is part of the problem with peoples' view of this field in general. The distinction isn't the symptom or what's actually going on, but rather the problem it is causing you. You can have all the same symptoms and simply one has the compulsion to flip a coin every hour, on the hour, and the other could be stabbing yourself in the arm every hour, on the hour. One of these "might" be OCD and the other is OCD. The difference is that one is definitely problematic and the other may not be.

This is the same distinction between addiction and just liking something a lot. If it becomes a problem then it's an addiction, but if it's not problematic it's not an addiction.

It's important to recognize this because, firstly, while it's current form might not be harmful you've shown yourself to have a glitch in your brain that is causing this type of behavior which means some other harmful thing can be triggered, and secondly, because as we age our minds can and often do degenerate causing once non-harmful things to become harmful.

Keep in mind that Psychology is a medical field and as such doesn't much concern itself with things that are "normal" and most of us normally have several quirks which aren't diagnosed as a disorder, but are clearly a glitch in the brain.

I started going to therapy in June and I've been diagnosed with an anxiety disorder, but it could be either Generalized Anxiety Disorder or Social Anxiety. It's still fairly early to tell and I have a number of different triggers which are connected to my low self esteem, self worth, and body image issues (a charming combination). Through having these issues, I have experienced panic attacks and exhibited avoidance behavior, but my cognitive disorders have not progressed to the point of not being able to leave the house. I just wanted to make it clear that just because someone isn't staying at home all the time or exhibiting an extreme behavior it doesn't mean that the disorder should be minimized. These disorders operate on a continuum--you can have a mild form of anxiety to a moderate form of anxiety and to an extreme form of anxiety. You can still be functional with these disorders, but interacting with people in public can still be very troubling and difficult for people. 

So to all the other people with these mental illnesses/disorders, we're going to get through this. We'll push on. We just need to remember that we can get through this. :)

Nothing gets my goat more than someone claiming that they are 'so OCD' or another mental illness. When someone uses a condition such as obsessive compulsive disorder as a sort of weak description or quirk, it can actually be very harmful to those nearby who actually suffer from the disorder. It's difficult to hear something you struggle with on a daily basis trivialized, and it reinforces the existing prejudice against individuals who are really suffering. There's nothing inherently wrong with pointing out and recognizing habitual or obsessive behaviours, but people need to understand that they are simply that: behaviours, as opposed to a full-fledged mental disorder. Perhaps if mental illnesses were more widely understood and respected, it would be easier to make this distinction in everyday life. That's my hope for the future, at least.

Social Anxiety Disorder is pretty SAD when you think about it...mhm, I went there.

I've had OCD for about six years. It's contamination-based, so handwashing, cleaning, showering, etc, are par for the course. I'm doing very well right now, but at my worst I was indeed scrubbing my hands until they bled, taking up to six showers a day, refusing to touch a great deal of things, and more. The thoughts (obsessions) are so pervasive and disturbing, and you waste hours upon hours every day performing your compulsions. It was so devastating to my quality of life. I wouldn't wish that kind of constant, cutting dread and fear on my worst enemy. It destroyed a lot of my relationships because, who would have guessed, confiding your fears in your friends and relatives leads them to believe that you're calling them disgusting. People have freaked out on me, screamed at me, told me not to talk about it, you name it.

I don't really take offense when people use "OCD" frivolously, but I do feel kind of bummed about it, because that person probably doesn't understand the absolute crushing awfulness that is full-blown OCD. Just keep in mind that people who have OCD do know that their obsessions aren't rational. What makes it a disorder is that they still CAN'T STOP. Being logical and rational doesn't really help the fear go away, and getting upset with someone because they're being irrational or because their compulsions are inconvenient to you is unfair. I understand the frustration of watching someone behave so illogically, but always remember that nobody asked to have OCD. I would do anything to not have it, to go back to the time before I developed it. But that's my life now.
